_meta.description: Centralized knowledge check questions extracted from Guidewire academy slides

ch04-l01.question: What is the purpose of an account?
ch04-l01.answer:
An account gives PolicyCenter users the flexibility to create and manage a customer's account independent of policies with which the account may be associated. The ability to manage an account separately from a policy can be useful when assigning policy and account visibility to different types of users.

In addition, PolicyCenter utilizes the name clearance function to ensure that a person or company is not an existing account and that they are not represented by another producer for the given policy type.

ch04-l01.question: How many accounts can a policy be attached to?
ch04-l01.answer: A policy can belong to only one account.

ch04-l02.question: Is a transaction a job? Explain.
ch04-l02.answer:
The term "policy transaction" is typical in the industry and is used in the user interface.
The term "job" is used in the data model, in user interface configuration, and in
business rules.

ch04-l02.question: A customer calls and wants a new policy for another term at the end of policy term. What transaction is the customer asking for?
A customer wants a new coverage on an existing policy. What transaction will best suit this need?
ch04-l02.answer: A policy change is the most obvious transaction in this case. However, a rewrite may be needed depending on the coverage details.

ch04-l03.question: How many policy files can be associated with an account?

Of the primary entities discussed in this lesson (other than policy), which entity:
A. Is the money the insured (account) pays for the policy?
B. Is a risk exposure that can be protected by the policy?
C. Is a physical document detailing some policy aspect?
D. Can either be created on the policy or created on the account and reused on the policy? (two possible answers)
E. Is a value that further limits or defines the coverage?
ch04-l03.answer:
A. Premium
B. Coverable
C. Form
D. Contact or Location
E. Coverage Term

ch04-l04.question: Explain the purpose of the product model in terms of products, policies and coverages.
ch04-l04.answer:
The product model is the model that describes how products and policies, including
coverages and coverage terms, are configured in your version of PolicyCenter. The
business needs of your organization drive the product model.

ch04-l04.question: A stakeholder insists that the underwriting rules be configured in the product model. Does this request make sense, based on what you have learned in this lesson? Why or why not?
ch04-l04.answer:
This request does not make sense because the underwriting rules are not configured
within the product model. Underwriting rules are configured outside of the product
model.

ch04-l05.question: Based only on the submission wizard, what is the main screen which will likely trigger an underwriting issue first?
ch04-l05.answer:
Pre-Qualification is the screen that will likely trigger an underwriting issue first. Other
issues may be triggered later. (All underwriting issues appear on the Risk Analysis
Screen - UW Issues tab.)

ch04-l05.question: Where do users specify modifiers?
ch04-l05.answer:
In the LOB-specific section. For example, the Commercial Auto line has a dedicated
modifier page.

ch04-l05.question: In which screen does an underwriter review issues raised during the submission process?
ch04-l05.answer: Underwriters review the issues in the Risk Analysis screen, Underwriting Issues tab.

ch04-l05.question:
What conditions trigger asynchronous quoting?
Asynchronous quoting must be enabled in the PolicyCenter installation
When the number of coverables exceeds the threshold
If the current line of business supports asynchronous quoting
A, B, and C
A and C

In the base configuration, for which line of business is two-step quoting enabled?
A. Commercial property
B. Commercial auto
C. Businessowners
D. General liability
E. All of them

ch04-l06.question: What is the main purpose of “Tools” in PolicyCenter?
ch04-l06.answer: The Tools menu provides an easy way to obtain several important pieces of supporting information for a policy file.

ch04-l06.question: Where in the Tools would you be able to access the record of a PolicyCenter user’s thinking or strategy when working on a policy?
Which Tools option provides a way to access electronic or physical files that are associated with a policy, but are not necessarily part of the contract?
ch04-l06.answer: Documents. Note that Documents are not the same as Forms.

ch04-l07.question:
For each of the following, identify whether the statement applies to submission jobs, change jobs, or both.
A) It can be started manually.
B) It can only be executed from an existing policy.
C) It requires you to identify the producer of record.
D) It can be withdrawn.
E) It can be declined.
F) It requires a new quote to be generated.
ch04-l07.answer:
A. Both
B. Change
C. Submission
D. Both
E. Both
F. Both

ch04-l08.question: What are the three ways that a renewal job can end?
ch04-l08.answer: Renewed, non-renewal (when the insurer chooses not to renew the policy) or not taken (when the insured chooses not to renew the policy).

ch04-l08.question: Under what two circumstances is the renewal wizard typically used?
ch04-l08.answer: The renewal wizard is typically used when the renewal is started manually or when the policy must be changed at renewal time.

ch04-l08.question:
Consider a situation where the insured is offered a renewal, but never
makes the payment. What is the renewal’s state? HINT: The renewal flow
times out.
ch04-l08.answer: The renewal flow does time out, and the renewal term is Not Taken.

ch04-l08.question: How many pre-renewal directions can a policy have?
ch04-l08.answer:
A policy may have any number of pre-renewal directions, but there is only one active
pre-renewal renewal direction at a time.

ch04-l08.question: When should you not create a pre-renewal direction?
ch04-l08.answer:
You should not create a pre-renewal direction if you want to renew the policy and do
not need human review of the job while it's being executed.

ch04-l09.question:
Cancellations and reinstatements always have the same effective date.
True or False?

Can you describe a situation where you might use a rewrite rather than a
policy change?
ch04-l09.answer:
Answers vary with student knowledge. A rewrite includes an extreme change that can
not be covered by a simple policy change transaction. This may include a change to
the policy effective date or to the producer of record.

ch04-l09.question: Describe the effective date for a rewrite.
ch04-l09.answer:
The effective date for a rewrite may coincide with the cancellation date or it may be
after the cancellation date.

ch04-l10.question: What makes a transaction out-of-sequence?
ch04-l10.answer:
A transaction is out-of-sequence if it is entered after some other bound transaction but
has an effective date earlier than the effective date of the first bound transaction.

ch04-l10.question: Can a submission be out-of-sequence? Why or why not?
ch04-l10.answer:
No, a submission can never be out-of-sequence. A submission creates a policy and
therefore must be the first transaction that can be issued against a policy. You cannot
have transactions effective earlier than the policy's creation date.

ch04-l10.question:
Can a change be out-of-sequence? When you start an out-of-sequence
transaction, how do you know that it is an out-of-sequence transaction?
ch04-l10.answer:
Yes, a change can be out-of-sequence. PolicyCenter displays an "out-of-sequence"
dialog box before starting the wizard and displays a warning label at the top of the
wizard screens.

ch04-l10.question:
What criteria does PolicyCenter use to determine if an out-of-sequence
transaction conflicts with a "later effective" transaction?
ch04-l10.answer:
If each transaction changes a single given field to a different value, then the two
transactions are in conflict.

ch04-l10.question: If there are no conflicts, what additional work must the end user do?
ch04-l10.answer: When there are no conflicts, there is no additional work. PolicyCenter automatically merges the data from the two transactions.

ch04-l10.question: If there is at least one conflict, what additional work must the end user do?
ch04-l10.answer: For each conflict, the end user must identify whether or not the earlier effective-dated value overrides the future effective-dated value in the future slice of the policy.

ch04-l11.question:
Answer true or false:
An internal user could be assigned a producer code for any organization.

ch04-l12.question: What is a producer code? What does it identify?
ch04-l12.answer: A producer code is a unique ID (alphanumeric) assigned by the insurer to determine what a producer can do. Producer code and its description identify the sales agent that sold the policy.

ch04-l12.question: What is an organization?
ch04-l12.answer:
An organization is a business entity which represents either the Insurer itself or an
external company for any set of users, typically producers.

ch04-l12.question:
Which External User Access level allows the external users to be
assigned to groups and producer codes from internal and any external
organization?
A. FULLYRESTRICTED
B. PROTECTINTERNAL
C. ALLOWINTERNAL
D. None of the above

ch04-l13.question:
What role does the document production system play in terms of form
generation?
ch04-l13.answer: The document production system is responsible for creating form content using the form metadata, policy data, and form template.

ch04-l13.question: When can PolicyCenter add forms to the policy?
ch04-l13.answer: PolicyCenter can add forms to a policy at quote and at bind.

ch04-l13.question: Describe form inference.
ch04-l13.answer:
Form inference is how PolicyCenter determines what forms to add to a policy.
PolicyCenter generates forms based on details that the user has entered. Users
specify coverages, exclusions and other details that give PolicyCenter the information
needed to run form inference logic.

ch04-l14.question: When is an underwriting issue raised?
ch04-l14.answer: Underwriting issues are raised when policy choices meet the conditions defined in the underwriting rules or Gosu code. In certain situations, underwriters can add issues manually depending on their permissions.

ch04-l14.question: Where are the underwriting issues displayed?
ch04-l14.answer: Underwriting issues are displayed on the Risk Analysis page under the tab - UW Issues.

ch04-l14.question: What decides when an underwriting issue is raised, checking set or blocking point?
ch04-l14.answer: Checking set decides at which point an underwriting issue should be raised. For example, whether an issue should be raised at pre-quote, bind or issue.

ch04-l14.question: Who can approve or reject underwriting issues? How is this decided?
ch04-l14.answer: A user, normally an underwriter or an agent, can approve or reject underwriting issues depending on their authority grants.

ch04-l14.question:
Answer true or false:
A. An approved UW issue cannot be reopened?
B. An agent can reject an UW issue?
ch04-l14.answer:
Correct answers:
A. False
B. True

ch04-l16.question: A set of "legal and binding" information about the product is described where?
ch04-l16.answer: In the policy line (the PolicyLine pattern).

ch04-l16.question: Although products are the first level of hierarchy in the product model, what should you set up before you set up products?
ch04-l16.answer: Although products are at the top of the hierarchy, products must be associated with at least one policy line and therefore policy lines must be configured before you configure a product for the product model.

ch04-l16.question: Can a single product having multiple policy line patterns exist? Give an example.
ch04-l16.answer: A package can have a single product that includes multiple policy line patterns. The base configuration includes a Commercial Package product that includes three policy lines: General Liability, Commercial Property, and Inland Marine.

ch04-l17.question: What is a coverable?
ch04-l17.answer: A coverable is an exposure to risk and is not a pattern in product model.

ch04-l17.question: What is a coverage?
ch04-l17.answer: Coverages are patterns in the product model where each coverage pattern is associated with a relevant entity.

ch04-l17.question: Define and give an example of a coverage category.
ch04-l17.answer: A coverage category is a group of one or more logically related coverage patterns.

ch04-l18.question: What is a coverage term?
ch04-l18.answer: A coverage term is a value that measures or further defines a specific coverage.

ch04-l19.question: What is availability?
ch04-l19.answer:
Availability in the user interface means that a coverage (or any other pattern on which
the availability is set), either shows up or does not show up in the application.

ch04-l19.question:
List at least two factors that influences the availability of a coverage
pattern.
ch04-l19.answer:
In PolicyCenter, the availability of a coverage pattern or any other pattern is based on
different factors including:
Start and end effective dates
Industry code
Underwriting company
Policy transaction type

ch04-l19.question: All of the product model patterns have availability logic, except for?
What is grandfathering?
ch04-l19.answer:
Grandfathering lets insurers continue to offer coverage patterns (or other patterns)
even though they may not be available to new customers.

ch04-l19.question:
Which patterns have grandfathering availability?

A) Coverage
B) Product
C) PolicyLine
D) Condition
E) Coverage term
ch04-l19.answer: The correct answers are A), D), and E).

ch04-l20.question: What is a question set and when should it be used?
ch04-l20.answer:
Question sets are used primarily to evaluate risk and qualification for an insurance
product. Question sets are used to determine whether a person qualifies for a
particular product, either right before they enter the wizard or through accumulated
information indicating an unacceptably large level of risk that isn't tied to any one
single issue.

ch04-l20.question: What is an offering and what is its purpose?
ch04-l20.answer:
An Offering lets insurers define different product types based on existing base product
definitions. The primary use case of offerings is to define specific product types.

ch04-l20.question: List at least two factors that make an offering available.
ch04-l20.answer: Start and end date, Job type, State, Industry, offerings question set answers.

ch04-l21.question:
For the Personal Auto policy line, why are there two possible values for a
modifier’s "modifier type"?
ch04-l21.answer:
In Personal Auto, a modifier can be associated with the policy line or to a specific
vehicle. When creating the modifier, you specify a modifier type to denote if it is policy
line level (PAModifier) or vehicle level (PAVehicleModifier).

ch04-l21.question: When do you need to add values to the RateFactorType typelist?
ch04-l21.answer: You need to add typecodes to the RateFactorType typelist when you create a schedule rate modifier and the desired rate factors don't already exist.

ch04-l22.question: Describe a business situation that calls for a contingency. Draw upon your industry experience as you come up with ideas.
ch04-l22.answer: Answers vary by audience, but the most common answer is getting a student report card to offer a personal auto policy discount.

ch04-l22.question: Can you add extra information to a Contingency? Give one or more examples.
ch04-l22.answer: Yes. You can add Notes, Documents, and Activities to a Contingency.

ch04-l22.question: Give one or more examples of appropriate actions related to a contingency.
ch04-l22.answer: Changing the policy, canceling the policy, or canceling and rewriting the policy.

ch04-l23.question: Distinguish underwriting (UW) referral reasons from an UW issue.
ch04-l23.answer:
The underwriting referral reason is specific to a policy. When it generates an underwriting issue, the transaction will not progress further. UW referral reasons are often manually created, cannot be approved, and are manually deleted (or through an API). UW referral reasons persist with the policy.
Underwriting issues are related to the transaction. When something is notable about this transaction requiring the attention of underwriting. They are often automatically generated, and are usually automatically removed when the cause no longer exists.

ch04-l24.question: At least two examples of how documents might be used in a policy.
ch04-l24.answer:
Track information that documents the assets covered by the policy (i.e., photographs of jewelry, diagrams of the workplace floor plan).
Track information used to rate the policy (i.e., assessments from property inspectors). Record correspondences with the insured.

ch04-l24.question: What are the two ways that electronic documents can be added to PolicyCenter?
ch04-l24.answer:
Documents can be added by:
+ Uploading (linking) to an existing document
+ Creating a new document from a template

ch04-l24.question: When a document already exists in PolicyCenter and you choose to edit it, where is the edited copy stored while it is being edited? What must you do to have the edited copy replace the master copy?
ch04-l24.answer: The edited copy is stored on your computer. To have it replace the master copy, you must click the Upload button on the Documents screen.

ch04-l25.question:
For the following descriptions, identify whether it applies to Documents, Notes or both Documents and Notes.
a) Involves integration with a third-party system
b) Created within an account, policy or contingency
c) Has a MIME type
d) Can use a template to create it
ch04-l25.answer:
a) Documents
b) Documents and Notes
c) Documents
d) Documents and Notes

ch04-l26.question: Give one example of how an activity can help users manage their work.
ch04-l26.answer: Assign work to a user, alert users to certain events, manage how policy jobs are completed.

ch04-l26.question: What business objects can have an associated activity?
What is an activity pattern?
ch04-l26.answer: An activity pattern is a description of how to create a specific activity.

ch04-l26.question: Is an activity always assigned to a group? A user?
ch04-l26.answer:
Activities can be assigned to users, groups or queues. In addition, a user is assigned
to a group; a queue contains activities assigned to a group.

ch04-l26.question: Who can modify an activity?
ch04-l26.answer: The activity owner and anyone with manager permissions.

ch04-l27.question: Name some of the user roles in PolicyCenter.
When does PolicyCenter determine which permissions a given user has?
ch04-l27.answer:
PolicyCenter determines the permissions for a given user when that user logs in and
every time when the user queries the server.

ch04-l27.question: How many permissions can a given role have?
ch04-l27.answer:
A role can have any number of permissions. PolicyCenter has certain zero-permission
roles in the base product to act as placeholders.

ch04-l27.question: How many roles can a given user have?
ch04-l27.answer:
A user can have any number of roles. A user must have at least one role in order to be
able to work in PolicyCenter. A user with broader responsibility can be given additional
roles so that they are able to accomplish these responsibilities.

ch04-l27.question:
How could you easily determine which roles enable users to create
accounts?
ch04-l27.answer:
View the create accounts permissions in the security dictionary to see which roles the
permission has been added to.

ch04-l28.question: What are the three types of PolicyCenter validation?
ch04-l28.answer:
Validation with field validators, validation during save and validation on demand which
can be run in a job wizard step or at a certain time in a job.

ch04-l28.question: What is the difference between an error and a waming?
ch04-l28.answer:
Errors block the action that the user was taking. Warnings are non-blocking and allow
the user to proceed to the next step and continue performing actions.

ch04-l29.question: What are the two types of premium audit?
ch04-l29.answer:
The two types of premium audit are: final audits and premium reports.
A final audit contains the verified, ultimate cost for a variable basis policy and usually
occurs at the end of the policy term.
A premium report is a premium bill issued at regular intervals throughout policy term
based on reported values.

ch04-l29.question: What are the different audit roles available in PolicyCenter?
ch04-l29.answer:
The different roles in PolicyCenter are premium auditor, audit examiner, and audit
supervisor.

ch04-l29.question: What are the different premium audit methods?
ch04-l29.answer: The different audit methods are physically, by phone, voluntary or estimated.

ch04-l30.question: List the three main components in PolicyCenter Rating Management.
ch04-l30.answer:
For an efficient implementation, rating specialists and actuaries should identify rate
flow, rate tables, rate routines. Note: rate routines use parameter sets.

ch05-l01.question: What does an end user need to access a Guidewire application?
ch05-l01.answer: A supported web browser and a valid username and password.

ch05-l01.question: When a user attempts to log into ClaimCenter, what three pieces of information does the application attempt to determine?
ch05-l01.answer:
1.Whether or not the user can be authenticated,
2.What are the user's roles (permissions), and
3.What is the user's startup page.

ch05-l01.question: What is one thing that determines what data is gathered on a claim intake screen?
ch05-l01.answer: The type of claim (personal auto, homeowners, worker's comp.)

ch05-l01.question: What is the purpose of an exposure?
ch05-l01.answer: An exposure is used to track potential payments on one coverage, for one claimant.

ch05-l01.question: What are two mechanisms used to determine if a transaction requires approval?
ch05-l01.answer:
Authority limits and transaction approval rules are used to identify which transactions
require approval.

ch05-l02.question: Within a claim, what is an incident?
ch05-l02.answer: An incident is the “what” that was lost or damaged.

ch05-l02.question: What are the three types of Service Requests?
ch05-l02.answer:
Quote only
Quote and service
Service only

ch05-l02.question: What is an exposure?
ch05-l02.answer:
An exposure is used to track a potential indemnity from one coverage to one
claimant.

ch05-l02.question: What is a set of activities on a claim called?
In ClaimCenter, what two mechanisms are referred to as a check?
ch05-l02.answer: A physical paper check and an electronic funds transfer

ch05-l03.question: What are the two basic building blocks of the ClaimCenter organizational structure?
When does object assignment happen?
ch05-l03.answer: Object creation and manual object reassignment

ch05-l03.question: What are the six (6) assignable objects in a ClaimCenter base configuration?

ch05-l04.question: What are three ways that a claim can be entered into ClaimCenter?
ch05-l04.answer:
Portal
External application (FROI application)
New Claim Wizard

ch05-l04.question: What happens during the automated claim setup?
ch05-l04.answer:
The claim is segmented
The claim is assigned to a group and user
Activities may be created for work that must be done on the claim

ch05-l04.question: ae What is the purpose of segmentation?

ch05-l05.question: ae What is the purpose or use of Segmentation?
ch05-l05.answer:
Segmentation is used to identify a high-level strategy for processing a claim or
exposure.

ch05-l05.question: What is the purpose of Assignment in the Automated Claim Setup?
ch05-l05.answer: To determine the owner(s) of both claims and exposures.

ch05-l05.question:
What are two attributes of a Group that are used in determining

x assignment?
ch05-l05.answer:
x assignment?
Group Type
Group Region

ch05-l05.question:
What are the lowest and the highest levels of maturity of a claim and

x exposure?
ch05-l05.answer:
x exposure?
New Loss Completion
Ability to Pay

ch05-l06.question:
How does ClaimCenter manage a contact that has multiple relationships
x toaclaim?
ch05-l06.answer:
x toaclaim?
Through the ClaimContact entity

ch05-l06.question: Whatis an incident?
ch05-l06.answer:
An incident is an item that was lost or damaged, such as a vehicle, property, or person
suffering one or more injuries.

ch05-l06.question: What is an exposure?
ch05-l06.answer:
Exposures are the mechanism used by ClaimCenter to track the progress of each
possible payment in compensation for a loss.

ch05-l07.question: What is a main goal of adjudication?
ch05-l07.answer:
To determine if a claim should be paid, and if so, how much should be paid to make
the claimant whole again.

ch05-l07.question: InClaimCenter terms, what is an incident?
ch05-l07.answer:
An incident is a single instance of loss. It is the property or person that is damaged or
injured.

ch05-l07.question: What is the purpose of an exposure?
ch05-l07.answer: An exposure is the mechanism that ClaimCenter uses to track potential payments for one coverage to one claimant.

ch05-l07.question: What is the purpose of a reserve line?
ch05-l07.answer: A reserve line is an amount of money set aside for expected payments related to a given exposure. It is defined by the exposure, a cost type, and a cost category.

ch05-l08.question: What is an ICD-10 code used for on a Workers’ Compensation claim?
ch05-l08.answer: An ICD-10 code is used to officially identify the medical diagnosis and path of treatment for an injury or illness. ICD-10 codes are a standard medical classification system used throughout the world.

ch05-l08.question: Why would a WC claim need Medical Case Management?
ch05-l08.answer: If the injury or illness is severe, long-term or complicated, or if there are many decisions to be made about differing treatments that may or may not be covered

ch05-l08.question: Jim is a welder that is injured and hospitalized for a month. The following two months, he works a desk job while recuperating. What benefit types could Jim be paid?
ch05-l08.answer: Jim would first be paid TTD (Temporary Total Disability) and then paid TPD (Temporary Partial Disability)

ch05-l08.question: Rachel is a security officer who is injured and suffers back pain for several months; but is able to work part time. Her treatment plateaus, and she still works in a limited capacity after treatment ends (MMI is reached). What benefit types could Rachel be paid?
ch05-l08.answer: Rachel would first be paid TPD (Temporary Partial Disability) because she can still work, but then could be paid PPD (Permanent Partial Disability) because her disability persists after MMI.

ch05-l08.question: What is the Differential, and what is it used for?
ch05-l08.answer: The Differential (the AWW minus the Post-injury wage) is used to calculate TPD (Temporary Partial Disability). The Differential itself is usually multiplied by 2/3 to arrive at the maximum weekly TPD benefit.

ch05-l09.question: What is the relationship between a check and a reserve line?
ch05-l09.answer: A check is a single transfer of money from one or more reserve lines to one or more individuals or organizations.

ch05-l09.question: What uniquely identifies a reserve line?
ch05-l09.answer: Reserve lines are uniquely defined by exposure, cost type, and cost category.

ch05-l09.question: What is the Total Incurred Gross?
ch05-l09.answer: Open Reserves + Past Payments. In other words, it is the total of all approved reserves, minus any eroding payments, plus all submitted payments with a scheduled date before or on the current date.

ch05-l09.question: What is the Total Paid?
ch05-l09.answer: The sum of all approved payments with scheduled send date today or earlier.

ch05-l10.question:
Betty Baker went through the payment wizard one time. She specified
three payees (and there were no joint payees or recurring payments).
Based on this information alone:
A. Can you tell how many CheckSets there are?
B. Can you tell how many checks there are?
C. Can you tell how many payment transactions there are?
ch05-l10.answer:
A. Yes. There is one. (Each iteration of the payment wizard creates one checkset.)
B. Yes. There are three. (Unless there are joint payees, each payee has a separate check. Unless there are recurring checks, then for three payees, there must be three checks.)
C. No. You can't tell. (The number of payment transactions is not tied to the number of payees.)

ch05-l10.question: A check includes a $200 final payment from a $500 reserve line. Why does ClaimCenter create a second transaction? What is the dollar amount of this transaction?
ch05-l10.answer: The second transaction is used to zero out the reserve line. The dollar amount of this transaction will be -$300, since there is $300 remaining after the $200 payment transaction.

ch05-l10.question: In what status must a check be for a user to delete the check?
Can you start the payment wizard when the claim is not at “ability to pay"? Why?
ch05-l10.answer: No. Validation rules prevent you from starting the payment wizard if the claim is not at “ability to pay”.

ch05-l11.question:
Does a transaction require approval when:
A) It is not flagged by transaction approval rules but exceeds the user's authority limits?
B) It does not exceed the user's authority limits but is flagged by transaction approval rules?
C) It exceeds the user's authority limits and is flagged by transaction approval rules?
ch05-l11.answer: The answer for all three is the same. The transaction requires approval in all three cases.

ch05-l11.question: An authority limit consists of criteria and an amount. What three values can optionally be specified to create the condition?
ch05-l11.answer: Policy type, coverage type, and cost type.

ch05-l11.question: What two things does ClaimCenter do when it determines that a transaction requires approval?
ch05-l11.answer: It sets the transaction status to pending approval and it creates an approval activity (which is typically routed to a supervisor).

ch05-l12.question: What claim condition prevents any type of payment against an exposure?
ch05-l12.answer: Maturity level (claim and exposure must be at ability to pay for any payment to be made).

ch05-l12.question: What are some conditions that cause an unverified policy?
ch05-l12.answer:
* A policy is changed in ClaimCenter
* A policy is created in ClaimCenter

ch05-l12.question: What are some conditions that result in automatic CIQ?
ch05-l12.answer:
* Loss date is before the policy’s effective date,
* Loss date is after the policy’s expiration date,
* Status on the policy is other than In Force or Archived.

ch05-l12.question: What is constrained if a policy is under financial holds?
ch05-l12.answer: All cost type payments (expenses are allowed).

ch05-l12.question: If you reset the value that caused the CIQ, is CIQ removed?
ch05-l12.answer: No. Only a supervisor or someone with the correct permissions can remove CIQ manually.

ch05-l13.question: If “Tire Town” is in Address Book and is associated with three claims, how many contacts have the name “Tire Town"?
ch05-l13.answer: Four. There would be one contact in ContactManager and three in ClaimCenter. Every contact, whether it is linked or not, is a unique and separate object.

ch05-l13.question:
Is it common or uncommon to have a contact that exists only in
ClaimCenter? Only in ContactManager?
ch05-l13.answer: It is common to have a contact that exists only in ClaimCenter. This is true for contacts that are relevant to only one claim (such as a witness or passenger). It is uncommon to have a contact exist only in Address Book. The primary purpose for a contact in Address Book is to have it associated with multiple claims, and if it is associated with even one claim, then the contact will also exist in ClaimCenter.

ch05-l13.question: What is the purpose of a contact role?
ch05-l13.answer: A contact role identifies the relationship that the contact has with the claim (such as insured, witness, doctor, and so on).

ch05-l13.question: How can you tell if a contact is linked or in sync?
ch05-l13.answer: You can tell whether a contact is linked and/or in sync by selecting the contact from the Parties Involved — Contacts’ screen. A label on the Basics card identifies the contact's status.

ch05-l13.question: How many claims can a contact be associated with if the contact is only defined in ClaimCenter?
ch05-l13.answer: One. Each contact is created within a claim. If a contact (usually an insured) has multiple claims, there will be a separate contact on each of those claims.

ch05-l14.question: When does ClaimCenter determine which permissions a given user has?
ch05-l14.answer: ClaimCenter determines the permissions for a given user when that user logs in.

ch05-l14.question: How many permissions can a given role have?
ch05-l14.answer: A role can have any number of permissions, from zero (which would serve no business purpose but is theoretically possible) to all the permissions in the system.

ch05-l14.question: How many roles can a given user have?
ch05-l14.answer: A user can theoretically have any number of roles from Zero to all the roles in the system. A user must have at least one role in order to be able to do anything in ClaimCenter. A user who has broader responsibility than another user can be given additional roles so that they are able to accomplish these responsibilities.

ch05-l14.question:
How could you easily determine the number of roles that enable users to
create matters?
ch05-l14.answer:
You could view the create matter permission in the security dictionary to see which
roles contain that permission. Note that this only works for the base product, because
the security dictionary will not update based on any changes that a project team or
security administrator makes to the roles.

ch05-l14.question:
A given user appears on the access control list for claim 234-22-147282,
but that user cannot view or edit the claim. How could this happen?
ch05-l14.answer:
The user probably lacks the system permission to view and/or edit claims. In order to
view or edit a claim, the user must have the system permission and appear on the
ACL.

ch05-l14.question:
A security profile can specify criteria for three types of access. What are
the three types of access?
ch05-l14.answer: Own access, view access, edit access.

ch05-l14.question:
Two different claims that use the same security profile can have two
completely different access control lists. Why?
ch05-l14.answer:
The security profile generates a list of users based on the criteria. The users who meet
the criteria vary from claim to claim. For example, if a profile says only the claim owner
and members of his group can view and edit the claim, then two claims will have
different access control lists if they are owned by users in different groups.

ch05-l15.question:
A matter does not have to be assigned. (True or false?)
A) True
B) False
ch05-l15.answer:
False. Matters (like claims, activities, and exposures) must be assigned to a group
and a user.

ch05-l15.question:
Which of the following choices describes the correct sequence of steps
for an SIU review in the base application?
A. Create SIU review activity, supervisor completes SIU questionnaire, SIU
escalation activity created
B. User completes SIU questionnaire, SIU review activity created, SIU escalation
activity created
C. SIU escalation activity created, user completes SIU questionnaire, SIU review
activity created
D. User completes SIU questionnaire, SIU escalation activity created, SIU review
activity created
ch05-l15.answer:
A. Create SIU review activity, supervisor completes SIU questionnaire, SIU
escalation activity created
B. User completes SIU questionnaire, SIU review activity created, SIU
escalation activity created
C. SIU escalation activity created, user completes SIU questionnaire, SIU review
activity created
D. User completes SIU questionnaire, SIU escalation activity created, SIU review
activity created

ch05-l16.question:
Which parameter can set the Determine Compensability activity’s due
date on a claim?
A) Jurisdictional Benefit Parameter
B) PPD Min/Max
C) Waiting Period
D) Denial Period
ch05-l16.answer:
A) Jurisdictional Benefit Parameter
B) PPD Min/Max
C) Waiting Period
D) Denial Period

ch05-l16.question:
What is the purpose of an impairment rating on a claim? How is this
matched to admin parameters?
ch05-l16.answer:
An impairment rating specifies, for PPD, the degree of disability or loss of use the IW
has suffered as part of a permanent disability. It is matched to two admin parameters:
the PPD Min/Max and the PPD # of weeks (for a given jurisdiction and effective
start/end dates)

ch05-l16.question:
If you want to calculate a TTD weekly comp rate, what data on a claim
must exist to match admin parameters?
ch05-l16.answer:
Three pieces of data:
1. The state (jurisdiction)
2. The claim’s loss date or notice date
3. The worker's AWW.

ch05-l16.question:
'fyou want to calculate a PPD weekly comp rate, what data on a claim

x must exist to match admin parameters?
ch05-l16.answer:
Four pieces of data:
1. The state (jurisdiction)
2. The claim’s loss date or notice date
3. The worker's AWW.
4. The impairment rating (disability %)

ch05-l17.question:
What is the difference between a policy and a PolicyType in
¢ ClaimCenter?
ch05-l17.answer:
—— What is the difference between a policy and a PolicyType in
x ClaimCenter?
A policy is a product that is sold to customers, that promises to pay money when a

specified LossType occurs. It is a contract between the insurer and the insured.

A PolicyType identifies the line of business associated with a policy, and indicates the
coverages (Coverage Types) that can be associated with the policy.

ch05-l17.question: e What is the purpose of a CoverageSubtype?
ch05-l17.answer:
It connects CoverageTypes to ExposureTypes.
A CoverageSubtype is a pair of one CoverageType and one ExposureType. It
models the complex relationship between CoverageTypes and ExposureTypes as a
simple parent-child relationship that is similar to the other levels in the Line of
Business hierarchy.

ch05-l17.question: What are some examples of Coverage Types?
ch05-l17.answer:
What are some examples of Coverage Types?

o Building Coverage, Homeowners Medical Payments, Collision, General Liability,

Comprehensive, and Liability are a few examples of coverage types.

ch05-l18.question: What is a shared contact?
ch05-l18.answer: Ashared contact is one that exists in both ContactManager and ClaimCenter.

ch05-l18.question:
What differentiates ClaimCenter vendor contacts from ClaimCenter non-

Yo vendor contacts?
ch05-l18.answer:
What differentiates ClaimCenter vendor contacts from ClaimCenter non-
Yo vendor contacts?
In ClaimCenter, vendor contacts that are edited or created require approval from a

vendor manager on the ContactManager side.

ClaimCenter vendors are linked to ContactManager whereas non-vendors are not.

ch05-l18.question:
What happens when a newly created vendor contact is approved in
x ContactManager?
ch05-l18.answer: linked to the Address Book and is in sync (unless the contact has been unlinked).

ch05-l18.question:
What happens when a vendor manager adds documents to a vendor
x that has a role on a claim?
ch05-l18.answer:
What happens when a vendor manager adds documents to a vendor
x that has a role on a claim?

The documents are immediately available on the claim.

ch05-l18.question: What is the system of record for vendors?

What is one of the benefits or advantages of defining services for a

x vendor?
ch05-l18.answer:
What is one of the benefits or advantages of defining services for a

x vendor?

Defining services provides better search capability from ClaimCenter.

ch05-l19.question: What different types of requests can an adjuster make on a service request?
ch05-l19.answer: Perform Service, Quote, Quote and Perform service.

ch05-l19.question: What is one thing that will prevent a service from being marked completed?
ch05-l19.answer: If a service is a Quote and Perform Service request, it cannot be marked complete until after the quote is received and approved.

ch05-l19.question: When can an invoice be automatically paid?
ch05-l19.answer: When an invoice is entered for a service that is marked complete and there is a matching reserve line.

ch06-l05.question: How does BillingCenter determine the placement date of the first installment invoice item?
ch06-l05.answer: BillingCenter determines the placement date using the invoiced and days fields in the First Installment section on the payment plan.

ch06-l05.question: How does BillingCenter determine the placement date of the second installment invoice item when there is a down payment?
ch06-l05.answer: BillingCenter adds one payment interval (for example, a month) to the placement date for the first installment.

ch06-l05.question: The down payment and installment 1 have different placement dates. Why are they on the same invoice?
ch06-l05.answer: BillingCenter places each invoice item on the earliest available invoice that has the same or later date than the invoice item’s placement date. The first available invoice for both invoice items was dated 10/15/2018.

ch06-l05.question:
Suppose you have a policy period that uses a payment plan with monthly payment interval. A pro rata charge for the policy period has been converted into invoice items.
In this situation, which one of the statements below will always be true?
A) If the down payment is scheduled for January 1st, the first installment must be scheduled for February 1st.
B) If the first installment is scheduled for February 1st, the second installment must be scheduled for March 1st.
C) If the second installment is scheduled for March 1st, the third installment must be scheduled for April 1st.
ch06-l05.answer: C. With a monthly payment plan, all installments after the second installment occur at monthly intervals. If the first installment is on sequence, all installments after the first installment occur at monthly intervals.

ch06-l05.question: Which of these invoice treatments does BillingCenter support for a pro rata charge?
ch06-l05.answer:
These invoice treatments are supported for a pro rata change:
#1 a down payment and sequence of installments
#3 no down payment and an out-of-sequence first installment
#4 no down payment and a sequence of installments
Note: #2 is not supported (a down payment and an out-of-sequence first installment)

ch06-l05.question: What is the difference between a down payment and an out-of-sequence first installment?
ch06-l05.answer: The down payment amount is calculated as a percentage of the premium amount whereas an out-of-sequence first installment is for the same amount as the other installments for the same premium charge.

ch06-l05.question:
What is the main purpose of the charge breakdown feature?
A) Charge breakdowns provide charge details for policyholder invoices.
B) Charge breakdowns facilitate efficient charge slicing.
C) Charge breakdowns allow for more granular accounting.
ch06-l05.answer: A. Charge breakdowns provide charge details for policyholder invoices.

ch06-l07.question: Whats the status of every invoice initially after it is created?
ch06-l07.answer: A new invoice has a status of Planned.

ch06-l07.question: When and how does BillingCenter make an invoice billed?
ch06-l07.answer:
On the invoice bill date, the Invoice batch process changes the invoice status to
Billed.

ch06-l07.question: When and how does BillingCenter make an invoice due?
ch06-l07.answer:
One day after the invoice due date, the Invoice Due batch process changes the
invoice status to Due.

ch06-l07.question: When does BillingCenter add an invoice fee to an invoice?
ch06-l07.answer: The invoice fee is added when an invoice is billed.

ch06-l07.question: Where do you specify the amount of an invoice fee?

Consider the following invoice details and billing plan settings. What is the deadline for changing the payment request?

| 02/0/2020 02/11/2020 1000000345 No Planned $1,232.40
ch06-l07.answer:
3/07/2018 because the Draft Date is three days before the Due Date and the
payment request is fixed one day before the Draft Date.

ch06-l09.question: How does the unallocated money get distributed?
ch06-l09.answer: There are four batch processes that allocate money sitting in unapplied funds.

ch06-l09.question: What do you do when entering a batch of multiple payments, and the account number you have been given as a reference for a payment is not known by BillingCenter?
ch06-l09.answer: Select Suspense instead of Payment as the Type on the Multiple Payment Entry screen.

ch06-l09.question: Where is unallocated money held?
ch06-l09.answer:
In an unapplied fund, which can be Default Unapplied (if the account does not use
cash separation), Designated Unapplied (if the account uses cash separation), or a
SuspensePayment unapplied fund if the destination of the payment is unknown.

ch06-l09.question: When making a single payment on the Direct Bill Payment screen, why is it important to select the correct unapplied fund?
ch06-l09.answer:
Only those invoice items that are payable from the selected unapplied fund are
displayed in the Distribution tab. (In the next lesson, you will learn how to add other
items to the distribution.)

ch06-l10.question:
Complete each sentence by filling in the blanks with the correct word or phrase.
1. An invoice item that has not been fully paid is ____.
2. Every ____ has a single payment allocation plan.
3. Given these payment allocation steps: step 2 is relevant only if ____.
4. The Spread Excess Even priority applies to ____ invoice items only.
5. A batch process will never allocate money in an unapplied fund to invoice items that are ____.
6. The Policy Period and Invoice filters apply when a batch process is allocating a ____ but not when it is allocating ____.
ch06-l10.answer:
1. An invoice item that has not been fully paid is (e) unsettled.
2. Every (g) account has a single payment allocation plan.
3. Given these payment allocation steps: step 2 is relevant only if (f) there is not enough money to fully pay eligible items.
4. The Spread Excess Even priority applies to (c) planned invoice items only.
5. A batch process will never allocate money in an unapplied fund to invoice items that are (d) from a policy with a different unapplied fund.
6. The Policy Period and Invoice filters apply when a batch process is allocating a (b) payment but not when it is allocating (a) money from an unapplied fund.

ch06-l10.question: Assuming an account with policy-level billing and cash separation, can you add an invoice item from Policy A to a direct bill payment allocation for Policy B?
ch06-l10.answer:
Yes. Using the Direct Bill Payment screen:
1. Click Override Distribution.
2. Click Add Items.

ch06-l11.question:
Designate each action as one of: Automatic (in 1 step), Manual, Both, or Neither (can’t be done):
1) Move a payment to a suspense payment
2) Apply a suspense payment to an invoice item
3) Move a suspense payment from a Suspense Payment Unapplied fund to another unapplied fund
4) Change the target account # of a payment that has already been allocated
5) Add an invoice item from one policy to a payment distribution (allocation) of another policy
ch06-l11.answer:
1) Move a payment to a suspense payment Manual
2) Apply a suspense payment to an invoice item Neither
3) Move a suspense payment from a Suspense Payment Unapplied fund to another unapplied fund Both
4) Change the target account # of a payment that has already been allocated Manual
5) Add an invoice item from one policy to a payment distribution (allocation) of another policy Manual

ch06-l12.question: What purpose does the Workflow Writer batch process serve?
ch06-l12.answer: The Workflow Writer batch process checks for active workflows that are suspended until a date has been reached or an amount of time has elapsed.

ch06-l12.question: How does BillingCenter know which workflow to use to process a given delinquency?
ch06-l12.answer: The delinquency plan associates each delinquency reason with the appropriate workflow.

ch06-l12.question: How does a Billing Clerk know that a policy is in delinquency?
ch06-l12.answer: Alert bars on the Account Summary and Policy Summary screens inform users of an active delinquency. Also, delinquencies are listed on the My Delinquencies screen on the Desktop.

ch06-l12.question:
Given the delinquency shown below, what needs to happen to move the delinquency forward?
Name: Account# (Oct 2, 2019)
Delinquencies
Events | Complete | Target Date | Completion Date | Description | Trigger
Yes | 09/25/2019 | 09/25/2019 | Dunning Letter 1 | Inception Date
Yes | 09/25/2019 | 09/25/2019 | Late Fee | Inception Date
— | 10/02/2019 | | Dunning Letter 2 | Inception Date +7 days
| 10/09/2019 | | Send Notice of Intent To Cancel | Inception Date + 14 days
| 11/09/2019 | | Collections | Inception Date + 45 days
| 01/23/2020 | | Writeoff | Inception Date + 120 days
ch06-l12.answer: The Workflow Writer batch process needs to be run to “wake up” the workflow, which is waiting on a date.

ch06-l12.question: How does an approval activity influence workflow?
ch06-l12.answer: An approval activity blocks workflow processing until it is either approved or rejected. Typically, the workflow performs different processing depending on the outcome of an approval activity.

ch06-l13.question: What are the primary entities that can be associated with a trouble ticket?
ch06-l13.answer: Account, producer, policy, and policy period.

ch06-l13.question: What is the result of associating an entity with a trouble ticket?
ch06-l13.answer:
An alert is displayed on the summary screen of the associated entity (if you select both the policy and policy period, you will see two alerts on the Policy Summary screen).
Also, any trouble ticket holds are applied to entities in the set of related entities.

ch06-l13.question: If a trouble ticket hold is placed on invoice sending, what happens on the bill date of a related invoice?
ch06-l13.answer:
On the bill date, the invoice status is changed to Carried Forward and the invoice
items are moved to the next planned invoice.

ch06-l13.question: If a hold is placed on delinquency and the trouble ticket is subsequently closed, what happens to incomplete delinquency events with target dates in the past?
ch06-l13.answer: The target dates of those events are adjusted to occur in the future.

ch06-l13.question: Why is it advisable to complete all associated activities before you close a trouble ticket?
ch06-l13.answer:
Each activity represents a task that needs to be done. If an activity is not completed,
this is an indication of a task that has not been completed.

ch06-l14.question: What event is represented by each number?
ch06-l14.answer:
BillingCenter receives billing request and constructs billing instruction
Commission earning event occurs
Commission is put in reserve
Commission is earned
Commission is paid
Commission day for producer is reached
Producer Payment batch process runs

ch06-l14.question: How many producers can earn commission from a single policy billing instruction?
How would you configure BillingCenter to pay different commission rates for different lines of business with the same producer?
ch06-l14.answer:
There are two ways to do this: (1) Set up commission subplans that define different
criteria for different types of cases or (2) set up different producer codes.

ch06-l14.question: How does BillingCenter determine which commission subplan applies to a given policy period?
ch06-l14.answer:
The conditional subplans have availability criteria, which BillingCenter checks against
the policy (LOB code), policy period (term number, assigned risk, state), and account
(evaluations, customer segments). If all the checks fail, the Default subplan is used.

ch06-l14.question: What is the role of the Default subplan?
ch06-l14.answer: If no conditional subplans match the policy, BillingCenter uses the Default subplan.

ch06-l14.question: When is commission earned?
ch06-l14.answer:
The timing of commission earning varies. It is determined by the Earn Commissions
setting on the commission subplan that is being used.

ch06-l14.question: Both commission overrides are available on the policy, on a charge, or
ch06-l14.answer:
Commission % is available on both; commission plan is available for the policy only;
commission amount is available for a charge only.

ch06-l15.question:
Within the context of policy changes, what process does BillingCenter
do for both positive and negative charges?
ch06-l15.answer: Both positive and negative charges are sliced into invoice items and are placed on invoices.

ch06-l15.question:
Within the context of policy changes, what process does BillingCenter
do for negative charges only?
ch06-l15.answer: BillingCenter uses the negative invoice items from a negative charge to pay unsettled positive invoice items.

ch06-l15.question: Whats the role of the return premium plan?
ch06-l15.answer: The return premium plan controls allocation of policy credits. Specifically, it specifies which unpaid items to pay with a policy credit and how to allocate the credit (for example, proportional, last to first, first to last).

ch06-l15.question: What does “collapsing future invoices” during cancellation involve?
ch06-l15.answer: Invoice items from all planned invoices are moved to the earliest planned invoice. Any policy credits allocated to positive invoice items are included in the move.

ch06-l15.question: What is the purpose of cancellation snapshots?
ch06-l15.answer: Cancellation snapshots provide the means of restoring the policy to a state that is as close to its original state as possible. Snapshots are needed because all planned invoices were collapsed onto a single invoice during the cancellation.

ch06-l15.question:
Policyholders want to avoid being billed for a down payment when
policies are renewed. How would you implement this requirement?
ch06-l15.answer: Add an override to the payment plan with a context of Renewal.

ch06-l16.question:
What does a billing clerk need to do to ensure that most refunds are sent
Y to policyholders?
ch06-l16.answer: No action is needed — BillingCenter automatically handles disbursements.

ch06-l16.question:
Identify the actor that initiates each step for a manual and an automatic
disbursement (1 of 2).

Identify the actor that initiates each step for a manual and an automatic
disbursement (2 of 2).

Given: $1000 in Default Unapplied, billed invoice items amounting to $200, and unbilled invoice items amounting to $600:

How much money is available for automatic disbursement if Unapplied
minus under contract is used for the calculation?

How much money is available for automatic disbursement if Unapplied
minus billed is used for the calculation?

ch06-l17.question: Suppose the Item Placement Cutoff Date on a payment plan has a value of Due Date. How does the setting impact invoice items on a policy that uses the payment plan?
ch06-l17.answer: If account-level billing is being used, each invoice item will be placed on the earliest invoice whose due date comes on or after the invoice item’s placement date. If policy-level billing is being used, the setting is ignored.

ch06-l17.question:
Suppose an account with account-level billing has three policies: a monthly, a yearly, and a weekly.
a. How many invoice streams does the account have?
b. If the account switches to policy-level billing, will the number of invoice streams be changed?
ch06-l17.answer:
a. Two. Monthly and yearly use the same invoice stream; weekly requires a second invoice stream.
b. Yes. The number of invoice streams will be either three (one for each policy) or four (one for each policy plus a monthly one for existing account-level charges such as a late fee).

ch06-l17.question: Suppose an account with account-level billing has three policies: a monthly, a yearly, and a weekly. How many unapplied funds does the account have?
ch06-l17.answer: One. Account-Level billing will only ever have one unapplied fund.

ch06-l17.question:
Identify all the valid combinations of billing level and unapplied fund:
a) Account-level billing with a single unapplied fund
b) Account-level billing with separate unapplied fund for each policy
c) Policy-level billing with a single unapplied fund
d) Policy-level billing with a separate unapplied fund for each policy
ch06-l17.answer: (a), (c), and (d) are valid combinations. However, c is rarely used because the primary reason for using policy-level billing is the ability to keep unapplied funds at the policy level.

ch06-l18.question: What are the three main characteristics of a list bill account?
ch06-l18.answer: A list bill account must be type List Bill. It must have at least one associated payment plan and one associated invoice stream that supports the payment interval on the payment plan.

ch06-l18.question: What are the restrictions for list bill accounts?
ch06-l18.answer:
A list bill account:
* Cannot own policies or hold collateral
* Always uses account-level billing
* Cannot be changed to a different account type

ch06-l19.question: Kashmira has been asked to issue a commission advance to a producer, but she doesn’t see a menu item for paying a commission advance. What is the problem?
ch06-l19.answer: Kashmira does not have a role that includes the permission to give a commission advance.

ch06-l19.question: When does BillingCenter determine which permissions a given user has?
ch06-l19.answer: BillingCenter determines the permissions for a user when that user logs in.

ch06-l19.question: How many roles can a given user have?
ch06-l19.answer: Theoretically, a user can have any number of roles from zero to many. Every user must have at least one role in order to be able to do something in BillingCenter. A user with broader responsibility than another user can be given additional roles so that they are able to accomplish these responsibilities.

ch06-l19.question: Kevin wants to update the address details for the Inna Starr account, but he cannot find the account. What is the problem?
ch06-l19.answer:
Most likely, the Irma Starr account is in a security zone that Kevin does not belong to.
Less likely is that Kevin’s assigned role or roles lack permission to view an account.

ch06-l19.question: How can you determine the number of roles that enable users to create trouble tickets?
ch06-l19.answer: Go to the Security Dictionary and view the create trouble ticket permission to see which roles the permission has been added to.

ch07-l01.question: What are the three tiers in the Guidewire application architecture?
ch07-l01.answer: Data, application, presentation (or user interface/web clients)

ch07-l01.question:
In which tier are the following used?
A) PCF files?
B) Gosu?
C) Data model entities?
ch07-l01.answer:
A) Presentation
B) Application
C) Data

ch07-l01.question: What is the purpose of the Guidewire platform?
ch07-l01.answer:
It contains common resources and configuration techniques that are shared by all
Guidewire applications. For example:
* Data model entities, PCF files and application logic to manage Users
* Data model entities and PCF files to create and assign Activities to other users

ch07-l01.question: How do you start Guidewire Studio?
ch07-l01.answer: Open the command line in the application folder and type “gwb studio”

ch07-l01.question: How do you start a Guidewire application from Guidewire Studio?

ch07-l02.question:
For each of the following, identify if it is stored as a database table, as a table column, or not stored in the database at all:
A) An entity (such as ABContact)
B) A physical data field (such as ABContact.CreateTime)
C) A virtual data field (such as ABContact.FullName)
D) A foreign key field (such as ABContact.AssignedUser)
ch07-l02.answer:
The correct responses are:
A) A table
B) A column
C) Not stored in the database (Technically, the source values are probably stored in the database. But the value of a virtual field itself is not stored as a separate value.)
D) A column (specifically a foreign key column to the relevant entity's table)

ch07-l02.question:
For each of the following, identify if it is stored as a database table, as a table column, or not stored in the database at all:
A) An array key field (such as ABContact.ContactNotes)
B) A typelist (such as VendorType)
C) A typekey field (such as ABContact.VendorType)
ch07-l02.answer:
The correct answers are:
A) Not stored in the database,
B) A table,
C) A column (specifically a foreign key column to the typelist's table)

ch07-l02.question: Name two circumstances in which you would execute the gwb genDataDictionary command.
ch07-l02.answer:
Possible answers:
You would execute genDataDictionary when you install the application and whenever you extend the Data Model.
You could also execute the command when you modify system permissions or some other aspect of access and therefore need to regenerate the Security Dictionary.

ch07-l03.question: How many ETX files can a given entity have?
ch07-l03.answer: One ETX file per entity in most cases.

ch07-l03.question:
What datatype do you enter for fields that will store....
A) String values?
B) Boolean values?
C) Numbers with decimal values?
ch07-l03.answer:
The correct responses are:
A) varchar
B) Bit
C) decimal

ch07-l03.question: Which datatypes require columnParam subelements?
ch07-l03.answer: varchar requires size and decimal which requires precision and scale

ch07-l03.question:
Under what circumstances would you want to regenerate the Data
Dictionary?
ch07-l03.answer:
You would want to regenerate the Data Dictionary whenever you extend the data
model and are concerned with data model validation beyond schema validation in the
Entity Editor. Regenerating the Data Dictionary also updates the dictionary files to
include the new fields (or entities) that you have created.

ch07-l03.question:
When does a Guidewire application actually modify the physical
structure of the database?
ch07-l03.answer: The physical structure of the database is modified only during start-up.

ch07-l03.question:
Describe some of the differences between the files in the
..\Metadata\Typelist\ and ...\Extensions\Typelist\ folders.
ch07-l03.answer:
Files under Metadata are read-only and are specific to the base configuration. You
cannot create Typelist files in the Metadata directory but can create Typelist files in the
Extensions directory. Only internal Typelist extension files (TIX) are in the Metadata
directory. Only external Typelist extension files (TTX) are in the Extensions directory.
Both directories contain Typelist (TT]) files.

ch07-l04.question:
Define the broad purpose for each element category:
A) Atomic widgets
B) Container widgets
C) Locations
ch07-l04.answer:
The correct responses are:
A) Atomic widgets display individual elements of data and/or functionality.
B) Container widgets group atomic widgets into logical groups.
C) Locations define how users move from one place in the application to the next.

ch07-l04.question: What does a PCF file define?
ch07-l04.answer: A PCF file defines a container widget or location and its contents.

ch07-l04.question:
What does each PCF editor convention mean?
A) A container widget shaded light blue
B) A light green line
C) A red background
ch07-l04.answer:
The correct responses are:
A) The container widget is referenced by the current PCF file and its contents are
contained in another file
B) For the currently selected widget tool, a new widget of that type will be placed in
the current location.
C) The PCF file has an error in it.

ch07-l04.question: How do you deploy PCF changes?
ch07-l04.answer:
You can restart the server. Restarting the server reloads PCF files at startup. A more
efficient approach for development is to Reload the PCF files. With internal tools
enabled, you can use the ALT+SHIFT+L keystroke to reload the PCF files. You can
also log in with an administrator user account and reload PCF files from the Internal
Tools Reload page.

ch07-l05.question: What must you specify in a widget's "value" property?
ch07-l05.answer: You must specify the field in the data model that the widget is bound to.

ch07-l05.question: When would you see the keyword "as" in the value property?
ch07-l05.answer: You would see the "as" when the container's base object is subtyped, and the field to which the widget must be bound is at one of the subtype levels.

ch07-l05.question: What is a display key?
ch07-l05.answer: A display key is an abstract display value referenced by a widget's label property. It can have one or more language-specific values, and when the UI is rendered, the value matching the user’s language is used.

ch07-l05.question: If you create a widget and specify only the ID, name, and label, is the widget visible? Editable? Required?
ch07-l05.answer: The widget will be visible, not editable, and not required.

ch07-l05.question: The screenshot shows a standard input widget. The customer requires a "long" date format. How could you implement this requirement?
ch07-l05.answer: You would need to configure the date input widget’s date format property. Setting this property to “long” will provide the desired behavior.

ch07-l05.question:
For the object "myContact" of type ABContact, what is the dot notation for the object's:
A) Preferred currency?
B) Notes?
C) Level of experience of myContact's assigned user?
D) Mobile phone (if it is a person)
ch07-l05.answer:
The correct responses are:
A) myContact.PreferredCurrency
B) myContact.ContactNotes
C) myContact.AssignedUser.ExperienceLevel
D) (myContact as ABPerson).CellPhone

ch07-l06.question: A Detail View that displays data must have at least one root object. Why?
ch07-l06.answer: The input widgets of a Detail View must reference some object in order to specify where the data they display comes from. This object must be the root object, or an object related to the root object. Therefore, in order to display data, a root object is needed.

ch07-l06.question:
A Detail View that displays data must have at least one input column.
Why?
ch07-l06.answer:
Input columns are used to organize atomic widgets in a Detail View. Every input
widget must be in an input column. If a Detail View displays data, then it has at least
one input widget, which means it must have at least one input column.

ch07-l06.question: What determines if a detail view panel is reusable or not?
ch07-l06.answer: If a Detail View is declared as the parent object of a PCF file, then it is reusable. It can be referenced by any number of other containers.

ch07-l06.question:
The def property of a Panel Ref usually has a value in the format of “x(y)”
A) What information comes before the parenthesis? (What is the x?)
B) What information is defined within the parenthesis? (What is the y?)
ch07-l06.answer:
The correct responses are:
A) The xis the name of the container to reference.
B) The y is a list of objects to pass to the child container to use as root objects.

ch07-l06.question: A Screen with Card references a Detail View. The Detail View contains a Text Input widget. To allow the user to edit the text input value, what must be set to editable?
ch07-l06.answer: The Input Widget and all of the containers that directly or indirectly contain it must be set to editable. The editable hierarchy begins with a location PCF Element. Assuming that the Screen declared in a Page location, then the Page location must be set to editable.

ch07-l06.question:
In Studio, can you add Edit Buttons directly to:
A) An inline Detail View widget?
B) A Detail View PCF file?
ch07-l06.answer:
No, you cannot add Edit Buttons directly to a Detail View widget. Typically, you
add a Toolbar to a Screen. Then you add Edit Buttons to the Toolbar. A Detail
View widget can be declared on a Screen.
No, you cannot add Edit Buttons directly to a Detail View PCF file. Typically, you
add a Toolbar to a Screen. Then you add Edit Buttons to the Toolbar. A Panel Ref
can reference the Detail View PCF file.

ch07-l06.question: Where do you typically add a toolbar with edit buttons?
ch07-l06.answer: You add a toolbar with edit buttons typically to the Screen container element.

ch07-l07.question:
Of the seven types of Locations listed...
Which two contain multiple screens and have their own info bar, actions menu, and side bar?

Of the seven types of Locations listed...
Which two renders a screen somewhere other than the screen area?

Of the seven types of Locations listed...
Which one typically navigates to one of several Locations based on business logic?

Of the seven types of Locations listed...
For each Location, what method would you usually use to navigate to it?
ch07-l07.answer:
Use go() to navigate to Pages, Location Groups, Wizards, and
Forwards.
Use push() to navigate to Popups and Exit Points.
Use goInWorkspace() to navigate to Worksheets.

ch07-l08.question: In the screenshot shown here, what is the array method to return the number of objects in the ContactNotes array? What is the value?
ch07-l08.answer:
var count = array.length or array.Count.
The total number of elements in the ContactNotes array is 5.

ch07-l08.question: In the screenshot shown here, what is the expression to return the count of notes that are regarding a problem? What is the count value?
ch07-l08.answer:
var countNotes = notes.countWhere( \ note ->
note.ContactNoteType == typekey.ContactNoteType.TC_ PROBLEM)
The total number of elements in the ContactNotes array is 1.

ch07-l08.question: In the screenshot shown here, what is an expression to return an array of ContactNotes where the note was created after January 31, 2014?

ch07-l09.question: What is the significance of a rule set's root entity?
ch07-l09.answer:
Every rule set is tied to an entity, known as the root entity. This determines which class
of objects the rule set is tied to. It also determines the object available to the rules in
the rule set when the rule set is triggered.

ch07-l09.question: What is the difference between an "execute all" rule set and an “exit after first action" rule set?
ch07-l09.answer: In an "execute all" rule set, all rules are executed. For example, validation rule sets are execute all. All validation conditions are checked, regardless of how many are true. In an "exit after first action" rule set, you do not typically execute all rules. When the first true condition is found, the action associated with that condition is taken and the rule set is exited. For example, assignment rule sets are exit after first action. Once an assignment is made, the rule set exits so that later code doesn't reassign the object.

ch07-l09.question: What is the effect of deactivating a rule?
ch07-l09.answer: The rule is not executed by the rules engine, which is useful in development for turning rules "on" and "off".

ch07-l10.question: What type of logic does a getter implement? A setter? A method?
ch07-l10.answer:
Getter: Logic that returns a derived value and does not take parameters or change other data.
Setter: Logic that takes a single input value and uses that to modify some other field or set of fields on the given object.
Method: Logic that requires parameters, changes data, or otherwise does more than simply deriving or setting a value.

ch07-l10.question: When you create a new enhancement, what code does Studio add for you automatically?
ch07-l10.answer: Studio automatically creates the package statement and the enhancement declaration statement and the type reference.

ch07-l10.question: For an enhancement on the ABContact entity, what code would you write to reference the given ABContact's AssignedUser field?
How do you create an enhancement method that returns no value?
ch07-l10.answer: You would create the method and optionally specify a return type of void.

ch07-l10.question: How do you reference enhancement properties and methods?
ch07-l10.answer: You reference enhancement properties and methods using the same syntax as base application entity properties and methods: object.propertyOrMethodName

ch07-l11.question: What does a code generator do?
ch07-l11.answer: A code generator processes a Guidewire resource defined in XML format (such as PCF file, entity, etc.) and produces a Gosu or Java class.

ch07-l11.question: Name at least one difference between incremental and bulk code generation.
ch07-l11.answer:
- incremental code generator can process a single file, while bulk code generator processes a set of files
- incremental code generation is not supported for every resource type
- bulk code generation can be started from the CodeGen menu or during project
- incremental code generation can be started on save or during project make while rebuild

ch07-l11.question: What is a breakpoint?
ch07-l11.answer: A breakpoint indicates a place where you want to suspend the execution of Gosu or Java code

ch07-l11.question: What is a PCF method? How can you debug a PCF method?
ch07-l11.answer: A PCF method is a plain old Gosu function that is local in a PCF file and executes some logic tied to that particular PCF file. You can open the <PCFFileName>Expressions.gs file, find the function and click on the gutter area at the desired line to set a breakpoint.

ch07-l12.question: What is the difference between an ETX file and an ETI file?
ch07-l12.answer: An ETX file extends a base application entity e.g. adding new columns. An ETI file defines a new custom entity from scratch.

ch07-l12.question: Does the base application have ETI files? Can developers create new ETI files? Where and how?
ch07-l12.answer: Yes, ETI files are in the base application. Developers can create new ETI files in the ...\extensions\entity\ folder using Guidewire Studio and the Entity Editor.

ch07-l12.question: If the ABLawyer entity has an array of Cases, what type of field is required on the Case entity?
ch07-l12.answer: The Case entity requires a foreign key field in the ETI definition that specifies the fkentity attribute as the ABLawyer entity.

ch07-l12.question:
To deploy data model changes, are you required to
A) Regenerate the Data Dictionary?
B) Restart the application server?
C) Restart Studio?
ch07-l12.answer:
A) No, you are not required to regenerate the data dictionary. Regenerating the data dictionary will identify any errors in the data model. If successful, the process will add new and modified entities to the data dictionary.
B) Yes, you must restart the application server to deploy the new and modified entities. The process creates new database tables and/or upgrades the database.
C) No, Studio is immediately aware of the data model changes. It is not necessary to restart Guidewire Studio.

ch07-l13.question:
In a List View:
A) What type of widget displays individual fields of data?
B) What type of widget organizes the individual fields of data?

Assume you have a list view panel with "anABContact" as the root object. The list view panel displays the contact’s addresses.
A) What would the row iterator's "value" property be set to?
B) What would the row iterator's "element name" be set to?
C) What other widgets would make use of the element name?
ch07-l13.answer:
A) anABContact.Addresses (assuming that the name of the addresses array is "Addresses")
B) The value is arbitrary, but it would probably be set to something like "currentAddress".
C) The cell widgets inside the row iterator's row. For example, a cell displaying the street would have a value of "currentAddress. Street".

ch07-l13.question: A list view typically needs a toolbar, even if it is read-only. Why?
ch07-l13.answer: The toolbar is needed for the paging controls. These controls are used to view each page of rows if the number of rows is greater than what can be displayed at one time.

ch07-l13.question: In what way is embedding a List View Panel in a detail view panel different from embedding a list view panel in a screen?
ch07-l13.answer: To embed a list view panel in a detail view panel, use a List View Input widget. To embed a list view panel in a screen (or card view panel or List Detail Panel), you use a Panel Ref widget.

ch07-l14.question: For a cell to be editable, the cell’s Editable property must be set to true. What other elements, if any, must also be editable to make the cell editable in the user interface?
ch07-l14.answer: The List View Panel’s Row Iterator Editable property must be set to true.

ch07-l14.question: When you drag an Iterator Buttons widget onto a toolbar, how many buttons are added?
Assume that an object called anABContact has an Addresses array and an Addresses list view panel whose Row Iterator is configured as shown. Identify the errors in how the property is configured.
ch07-l14.answer:
There are four errors:
1. The object is anABContact, not ABContact.
2. The method name starts with "addTo...", not "toAdd...".
3. The name of the array is missing from the end of the method name. (The method should be addToAddresses.)
4. The argument must reference the row iterator's element name, which is currentAddress.

ch07-l15.question: What are some of the differences between the files in the ..\Metadata\Typelist\ and...\Extensions\Typelist\ folders?
ch07-l15.answer:
Files under Metadata are read-only and are specific to the base configuration.
You cannot create Typelist files in the Metadata directory but can create Typelist files in the Extensions directory.
Only internal Typelist extension files (TIX) are in the Metadata directory.
Only external Typelist files (TTX) are in the Extensions directory.
Both directories contain Typelist (TT1) files.

ch07-l15.question:
Which is a valid code value for a Typecode in a food coloring Typelist?
A) RedDye#1
B) YellowDye40
C) OrangeDye:10
ch07-l15.answer:
A) Not valid
B) Valid
C) Not valid

ch07-l15.question: Which Typecode attribute determines the order in which Typecodes are listed in the user interface?
ch07-l15.answer: The priority attribute determines the sort order in the User Interface for a Typelist. After priority, the name (not code) determines the sort order. Entries with priority -1 appear at the end of the list.

ch07-l15.question: What does a Typefilter do?
ch07-l15.answer: Defines a named subset of the Typecodes that could be used as value for the associated Typekey field that references this Typelist.

ch07-l16.question: What are the three primary use cases for popups?
ch07-l16.answer: Viewing and editing existing objects, creating new objects, and executing popped searches.

ch07-l16.question: What happens if a location's canEdit property evaluates to false?
ch07-l16.answer: The screen and its contents are non-editable.

ch07-l16.question: What happens if a location's canVisit property evaluates to false?
ch07-l16.answer: The widget navigating to the location is either not visible or not clickable.

ch07-l17.question:
Assume that there is an Order entity that has an OrderNumber field. The field appears on two detail views: LegacyOrdersDV and NewOrdersDV.
A) Name a situation where you would implement validation logic for the OrderNumber field at the data model level.
B) Name a situation where you would implement validation logic for the OrderNumber field at the UI level.
ch07-l17.answer:
A) Possible answer: The OrderNumber field has a pattern, such as two characters, a hyphen, and five characters, and this pattern must be followed everywhere the field is used. Also, you want to localize the error message.
