B) Possible answer: On the detail view for orders imported from a legacy system, the order number could take any format. On the detail view for orders created in the Guidewire application, the order number must start with the characters "GW-*.

ch07-l17.question: What happens if a widget's validation expression returns null?
ch07-l17.answer:
The save is allowed—a return value of null signifies that the validation condition was
met.

ch07-l17.question:
In case of validation rules, if you have an existing reject statement which
raises only a warning, how would you change it to instead raise an error?
ch07-l17.answer:
You would swap the order of the final two pairs of arguments. The first pair should be
the last pair and vice versa.

ch07-l17.question:
The first argument of rejectField is a “relative path” to the object to
highlight. Why is it relevant to keep in mind that the path is relative?
ch07-l17.answer:
It is important to keep this in mind because the root object must be omitted from the
path. If you include the root object, then TrainingApp will not be able to find the field to
highlight.

ch07-l18.question: What are the primary use cases for input sets?
ch07-l18.answer:
Possible answers: (1) Reuse of widgets across detail view panels, (2) or logic shared
for a group of widgets such as editability and/or visibility (3) or targeted page update.

ch07-l18.question:
Which of the following can be included in input sets:
a) Embedded list views
b) Inputs
c) Input columns
d) Input dividers
e) Labels
ch07-l18.answer:
The correct answers are:
Embedded list views, Inputs, Input dividers, and Labels.

ch07-l18.question:
What is the difference between the "input set" widget and the "input set
ref" widget?
ch07-l18.answer:
The InputSet widget groups widgets together and is placed within an input column
within a detail view panel. You use an InputSetRef widget to reference an Input Set
PCF file. An Input Set PCF can be referenced by one or more InputSetRef widgets.
Input Set PCFs are reusable input sets.

ch07-l19.question: Name two properties that evaluate expressions.
ch07-l19.answer:
Possible answers include:
* editable
* required
* visible
* available

ch07-l19.question: How is a partial page update implemented?
ch07-l19.answer:
A partial page update is implemented by configuring dynamic widget behavior by
enabling targeted post on change. Often the dynamic widget behavior configuration
also includes configuring an expression for a widget property.

ch07-l19.question:
What are the three properties that you can configure for a widget with
targeted Post On Change enabled?
ch07-l19.answer: disablePostOnEnter, onChange, and (with earlier InsuranceSuite versions) target.

ch07-l20.question: What is a subtype entity?
ch07-l20.answer:
A subtype is an entity that is a child to a parent entity and inherits all fields from the
parent.

ch07-l20.question: What is a subtype entity extension?
ch07-l20.answer: A subtype extension is an entity extension of a base application subtype entity.

ch07-l20.question: Describe at least one limitation of relying heavily on subtype hierarchies.
ch07-l20.answer:
One major limitation of a subtype hierarchy is that a subtype entity can only have one parent entity and multiple inheritance (two or more direct parents) is not supported. In addition, the subtype always inherits the parents elements, meaning the subtype contains the parent fields.
For a deep hierarchy (many levels), this means the lowest child will inherit all the fields of the parents. Deep subtype hierarchies can result in very wide tables that are highly denormalized resulting in poor application performance.

ch07-l20.question: When you create a new subtype, why are you NOT able specify a table name?
ch07-l20.answer: You cannot specify a table name because the new subtype data is stored in the same table as the supertype.

ch07-l21.question: Name two business situations in which it might be useful to use modal PCFs.
ch07-l21.answer: Possible answers: Different types of contacts (individual vs. business); different lines of business (auto vs. property).

ch07-l21.question: For a given set of modal PCFs, what two things must all of the PCFs have in common?
ch07-l21.answer: All of the files must have the same required variables (identical in number, order, and type), as well as the same ID.

ch07-l21.question: Can a PCF have more than one mode?
Can the same mode be used by more than one PCF within the same modal set?
ch07-l21.answer: No. If the same mode is used in multiple PCFs in the same set, then the application cannot determine which file to use and a runtime error occurs.

ch07-l21.question: What happens if a reference identifies a mode, but there is no PCF with that mode in the set?
ch07-l21.answer: If a PCF with a mode of "default" exists, then that default is used. Otherwise, a runtime error occurs.

ch07-l22.question: For an ABPerson object, name an example of when the object's entity name might appear in the user interface.
ch07-l22.answer: Possible answers: a drop-down list that displays a list of ABPersons; an info bar widget with a value property set to the ABPerson's DisplayName.

ch07-l22.question: What property points to an object's default entity name type?
For which entities do you need to create an entity name file?
ch07-l22.answer:
Custom entities and other entities whose display names are referenced in the user
interface but do not already have entity names.

ch07-l22.question:
What must you do to deploy new entity name types or changes to
existing entity name types?

ch08-l01.question:
Which entities below answer the business question of what is covered
on the policy?
A) PolicyLine
B) Coverable
C) CoverableCov
D) Cost
E) Form
F) Job
ch08-l01.answer: Correct answers: A, B, C, D, E

ch08-l01.question:
Assume a given instance of PolicyCenter
has 2 policy lines, each with 3 coverables.
How many entities are there that store...
1. Coverables?
2. Coverages?
3. Costs?

What is the purpose of the
UserRoleAssignment entity?
ch08-l01.answer:
UserRoleAssignment is used to pair a
user/group combination with an ownable
object and a specific role on that object (such
as underwriter). An individual user can have
multiple roles.

ch08-l02.question:
When you navigate between locations in a location group:
a) What changes?

b) What remains the same?
ch08-l02.answer:
a) The contents of the screen area changes.

b) The menu links, menu actions, and info bar remain the same.

ch08-l02.question: What two things can a location ref point to?
ch08-l02.answer: A child location group or a page.

ch08-l02.question: What happens if a location group's canVisit attribute evaluates to false?
ch08-l02.answer:
When a location group's canVisit attribute is false, the location group is not rendered in
the user interface. For example, if the location group appears on a tab, the tab is not
rendered at all.

ch08-l02.question:
When viewing a location group PCF file in Studio, which Studio tab
specifies how to navigate to a particular location group?
ch08-l02.answer:
The Entry Points tab. This identifies the "navigation name" of the location group as
well as any objects needed when navigating to it.

ch08-l03.question:
Name three things that are true of a job wizard that are not true of a
location group.
ch08-l03.answer:
Possible answers:
* job wizard screens are ordered.
* job wizards have toolbars used to navigate through the ordered screens.
* job wizard screens can have conditional availability tied to where you are at in the
job wizard.

ch08-l03.question: Why would you want to put job wizard steps into a step group? A step set?
ch08-l03.answer:
You might put steps into a step set when you want to control the visibility or availability
of multiple steps with a single condition. You might put steps into a step group when
you want the steps to be indented with a single label displayed over all of them.

ch08-l03.question: What attribute controls the order of appearance of job wizard steps in the user interface?
ch08-l03.answer:
There is no attribute that controls the order of appearance. Order of appearance is
based on the order in which the wizard steps are listed in the PCF file.

ch08-l03.question: How does a step behave differently if you set its independent attribute to true?
ch08-l03.answer:
Setting a step’s independent attribute to true will list it at the bottom of the sidebar, and
it cannot be navigated to using the Back/Next toolbar buttons.

ch08-l03.question: What is a job wizard's entry point? What other elements of the user interface reference a job wizard's entry point?
ch08-l03.answer:
Ajob wizard's entry point is the internal name for the job wizard. It is used by
navigation widgets which navigate to the job wizard when clicked.

ch08-l04.question: Name the plugin that maps the AccountContactRole to the PolicyContactRole in the default application.
Name the types of contact patterns available that occur in the base configuration of PolicyCenter.
ch08-l04.answer: Normal, Singleton, Simple Details, Join Details.

ch08-l04.question: What is LocationNum?
ch08-l04.answer:
LocationNum is the field that stores the sequential location number for account and
policies.

ch08-l04.question: How are locations numbered between accounts and policies?
ch08-l04.answer:
Locations are numbered separately between accounts and policies using
LocationNum field.

ch08-l04.question: Which lines of business in the base configuration have extendable location related entities?
ch08-l04.answer: Inland Marine, Commercial Property and Businessowners

ch08-l05.question: What are EffDated entities?
ch08-l05.answer:
EffDated entities are created to track the state of an entity over effective time.
They have an effective date and an expiration date.

ch08-l05.question: What is the difference between effective time and model time?
ch08-l05.answer:
Model time is the actual real-world time when policies are created or jobs are bound.
Effective time is the time dimension of the policy itself within the policy period.

ch08-l06.question: What is underwriting authority?
ch08-l06.answer: Underwriting authority provides underwriting rules and an underwriting infrastructure which user can modify or augment.

ch08-l06.question: What does the UW Rule define?
ch08-l06.answer: The UW Rule defines the underwriting issues type, conditions to raise the issue in the base product.

ch08-l06.question: What is the rule context?
ch08-l06.answer: The rule context supplies data to the UW rule so that the objects in the context can be used to create rule conditions. It is defined in the context definition classes.

ch08-l06.question: What values should be used as IssueKey to raise issues? Should this value be changed after a rule is in production?
ch08-l06.answer: Values that uniquely identify the issue and do not change over the life time of the policy should be used to raise underwriting issues. Guidewire recommends that you do not change the algorithm for forming the key for an issue once that rule is in production.

ch08-l06.question: Name three blocking points for an issue.
What is a checking set?
ch08-l06.answer: A checking set represents a point in a job at which issues can be raised such as pre-quote, bind or pre-issuance.

ch08-l07.question: What is an authority grant?
ch08-l07.answer: Authority grants allow users to approve a specific issue defined in UW Rule.

ch08-l07.question: What is an authority profile?
ch08-l07.answer: Authority profiles are collections of authority grants and can be assigned to users.

ch08-l08.question: Name three policy-related objects in PolicyCenter on which class-based validation is performed.
ch08-l08.answer: Class-based validation can be performed on PolicyContactRole, PolicyLocation, PolicyPeriod, or any LOB entities, or any other policy-specific entities.

ch08-l08.question:
State true or false:
a) All entities in PolicyCenter can be validated.
b) All validation classes must have a validatelmpl or doValidate method.
c) The doValidate method should be last method in a class.
ch08-l08.answer:
a) True
b) True
c) False

ch08-l08.question:
Name the validation context method that produces a string of methods
that were visited as validation was performed.
ch08-l08.answer:
The showVisited() method shows a list of methods as a string that were visited as
validation was performed.

ch08-l08.question: Define validation chaining.
ch08-l08.answer:
Validation chaining is the process of one validation class calling another validation
class to perform additional validation checks.

ch08-l08.question:
Name the PCF attributes used to invoke class-based validation in a
popup and in a job wizard.
ch08-l08.answer: BeforeSave attribute for a job wizard step and beforeCommit attribute on a popup.

ch08-l09.question: Why do you need revisioned fields on contacts or locations?
ch08-l09.answer:
Revisioned fields are required on contacts or locations when some information is
considered part of the policy contract and thus cannot be changed once the policy is
bound and the contract written. If the field is revisioned, it can be changed on the
account level even after the policy is bound. The information is updated on the
account and can be obtained by policies for future jobs.

ch08-l09.question:
True or false: Contact data is always synced to account during
submission and issuance.

True or false: During a back dated policy change, contact data is copied
from policy to account.
ch08-l09.answer:
False. Contact data is not copied from policy to account for a back dated policy
change.

ch08-l09.question: How does PolicyCenter handle back dated changes on contact data?
ch08-l09.answer:
PolicyCenter creates activities and notes on the account specifying the changes made
to the policy. A user can decide whether to apply the changes or not at the account
level. The changes must be applied manually.

ch08-l10.question: What is a system permission?
ch08-l10.answer: System permissions are permissions defined in the SystemPermissionType typelist.

ch08-l10.question: Define static and object-based permissions. Give examples.
ch08-l10.answer:
Static permissions do not take any parameter as argument whereas object-based
permissions take an object as an argument.
Example of static permission — perm.System.viewteam.
Example of object-based permission — perm.Account.edit( account ).

ch08-l11.question: What are the three possible parent objects for an Activity?
What field is a unique internal name for an activity pattern?

ch08-l12.question: What is the difference between primary and secondary assignment?
ch08-l12.answer: In primary assignment, a single user is assigned ownership of the assigned object. In secondary assignment, one or more users are assigned to roles with respect to the assigned object.

ch08-l12.question:
When an activity is assigned by rules, which two rule sets are typically
executed? In what order?
ch08-l12.answer: First, global rules are executed. Then, default group rules are executed.

ch08-l12.question:
Under what circumstances can an activity be assigned without
assignment rules being executed?
ch08-l12.answer: When the activity is assigned to a specific user.

ch08-l12.question: Why are assignment methods always inside if statements in assignment rules?
ch08-l12.answer:
Assignment methods are always inside if statements because they might fail. For
example, an assignGroup method may not be able to find the specified group.
If the assignment succeeds, then the if statement causes control of flow to execute an
actions.exit() statement, which exits execution from the rule set.
If the assignment fails, then the actions.exit() statement is skipped and execution
proceeds to the next rule.

ch08-l12.question: What is the Default Owner of an object?
ch08-l12.answer:
Default Owner is a dummy user that objects are assigned to when global assignment
rules fail to assign the object to a group.

ch08-l13.question: What two classes exist for every job type?
ch08-l13.answer: The job class and the job process class.

ch08-l13.question: What is a branch?
ch08-l13.answer: The set of objects associated with one PolicyPeriod object.

ch08-l13.question: In what three ways can jobs be started?
ch08-l13.answer:
By users through the UI; by external systems through the APIs; and by PolicyCenter
batch processes.

ch08-l13.question: When does a job end?
ch08-l13.answer: When the job’s branch is promoted, withdrawn, or discarded.

ch08-l13.question: What determines the visibility of buttons in a job’s button set?
ch08-l13.answer: Can methods on the job process class.

ch09-l01.question: Everything under one tab in the tab bar is called...?
ch09-l01.answer: The correct answer is a location group.

ch09-l01.question: Which component of a location group provides navigation within the location group?
ch09-l01.answer: The correct answer is Location refs.

ch09-l01.question: What can a location ref widget refer?
ch09-l01.answer: The correct answer is a page or another location group.

ch09-l01.question: What does an info bar element define?
ch09-l01.answer: The correct answer is the informational widgets, like policy number and assigned adjuster, that appear at the top of a page.

ch09-l02.question: What is ClaimCenter’s line of business (LOB) model?
ch09-l02.answer: The correct answer is the hierarchy that organizes policies, coverages, and covered losses.

ch09-l02.question: What is the purpose of the Coverage Subtype in the LOB model?
ch09-l02.answer: The correct answer is that it provides a M:M mapping between coverage types and exposure types.

ch09-l02.question: Which two levels of the LOB model are not typically derived from the policy administration system?
ch09-l02.answer: The correct answers are exposure type and coverage subtype.

ch09-l02.question: Which typelist, outside of the LOB model, must every exposure type be associated with?
ch09-l02.answer: The correct answer is incident type.

ch09-l02.question:
Why does Guidewire recommend to not delete typecodes from the Line
of Business model?
ch09-l02.answer:
The correct answer is that it can result in inconsistencies which will cause the server
not to start.

ch09-l03.question: What is the structure of a wizard?
ch09-l03.answer:
The correct answer is it is a list of sequential (and optionally non-sequential) steps,
that together perform some complex task in a logical order, as a logical unit of work.

ch09-l03.question:
How does a wizard reference a screen, and how is this different from
how a location group references a screen?
ch09-l03.answer:
The correct answer is a wizard directly references a screen via a wizard step, as
opposed to a location group which references a screen via a page.

ch09-l03.question:
What happens when a screen’s mode property does not match any of
the defined modes?
ch09-l03.answer:
The correct answer is if there is a default mode defined, that mode of the screen is
displayed; otherwise, a runtime error occurs.

ch09-l04.question: What is the parent of a rule set called?
ch09-l04.answer: The correct answer is a rule set category.

ch09-l04.question:
Which component of a Gosu rule determines whether the rule will be
executed?
ch09-l04.answer:
The correct answer is the Condition, which must evaluate to true or false. If it
evaluates to true, the rule is executed.

ch09-l04.question: What triggers exception rules?
ch09-l04.answer:
The correct answer is when an object is in a specified state, such as an activity being
escalated.

ch09-l04.question: What triggers preupdate rules?
ch09-l04.answer:
The correct answer is when an attempt is made to update an entity, that is, to save it to
the database.

ch09-l05.question:
In the base configuration, what kinds of objects may be assigned to a
queue?
ch09-l05.answer: The correct answer is only Activities,

ch09-l05.question: What must be true of an entity for its objects to be assignable?
ch09-l05.answer: The correct answer is it must implement the CCAssignable delegate.

ch09-l05.question: What method ends the execution of a rule set?

ch09-l06.question: In what two ways does ClaimCenter validate data?
ch09-l06.answer: validation by field ensures that data is of valid type, range, and so on, while validation by rules manages and enforces object maturity.

ch09-l06.question: When are claims and exposures validated?
ch09-l06.answer: when an attempt is made to save them.

ch09-l06.question: What method would you use to reject a claim or exposure and indicate a specific field in that object?

ch09-l07.question: Which rule set category does not provide rules for both claims and exposures?
ch09-l07.answer: Initial Reserve rules, which provides rules only at the exposure level.

ch09-l07.question: For which rule set category do exposure rules run before claim rules? Why?
ch09-l07.answer: Segmentation. Exposure rules are run first because claim segmentation typically depends upon the outcome of exposure segmentation.

ch09-l07.question:
What type of objects are most likely to be created in
(a) Presetup rules?
(b) Workplan rules?
ch09-l07.answer:
For (a) Presetup rules, is exposures.
For (b) Workplan rules is activities.

ch09-l07.question:
Which claim-level rule set categories are also executed outside of claim setup?

For each, give a non-claim setup example of when they might run.
ch09-l07.answer:
Assignment rules — Run whenever an object such as an activity is reassigned using automated assignment.
Preupdate rules — Run whenever an object such as an exposure is created or modified.
Validation rules — Run whenever an object such as an activity is created or modified.

ch09-l07.question: In the diagram, what rule sets are included in “activity rules”?
ch09-l07.answer: activity presetup, activity assignment, activity postsetup, activity preupdate, and activity validation.

ch09-l08.question: What is the difference between a contact type and a contact role?
ch09-l08.answer: Type and subtype are object types in the data model. Contact roles identify the contact’s relationship to the claim or exposure.

ch09-l08.question: What is the difference between a contact role type constraint and an entity role constraint?
ch09-l08.answer:
The correct answer is contact role type constraints determine which subtypes of the
contact entity can have the role. Entity role constraints determines what entities can
“own” the role, and how many contacts with the role are allowed on the entity.

ch09-l08.question: If you need to add a claim contact to a detail view, which widget type should you use?
ch09-l08.answer: The correct answer is a claim contact input.

ch09-l09.question: What are the four basic types of a financial transaction in ClaimCenter?
ch09-l09.answer:
The correct answers are:
Reserve transaction
Payment transaction
Recovery reserve transaction
Recovery transaction

ch09-l09.question: ReserveSet and PaymentSet are subtypes of what parent type?

In the base ClaimCenter configuration, making a final payment on an
exposure closes the exposure; and making a final payment on the last
exposure on a claim closes the claim.

If you want to change this behavior, what file should you edit?

What kind of library methods does ClaimCenter provide for getting
financial measures in rules?
ch09-l09.answer: The correct answer is FinancialsCalculations methods

ch09-l09.question: How does ClaimCenter exit the validation rule set? Why?
ch09-l09.answer:
The actions.exit() method is not used; rather, the rule set exits when all transaction
validation rules have been executed, in the order in which they appear in Studio.
This is because success (or failure) of one validation condition does not necessarily
mean that another will not fail (or succeed). By running all the rules, ClaimCenter
provides a full list of any conditions that must be remedied before continuing.

ch09-l10.question: At what transactional hierarchy level does approval happen?
ch09-l10.answer: The correct answer is at the level of the TransactionSet

ch09-l10.question: What happens after a transaction set is approved? Why?
ch09-l10.answer:
The correct answer is approval rules are re-executed using the permissions of the last
approving user. This enables multi-stage approvals.

ch09-l10.question:
What are two mechanisms for identifying transactions that need
approval?
If a user has a $15000 approval limit for Comprehensive coverage, what effect does that have on their approval limit for Collision coverage?
ch09-l10.answer: Unless they have another limit line that enables Collision coverage, they cannot approve Collision transactions at all.

ch09-l10.question: What do transaction approval rules and approval routing rules, respectively, do?
ch09-l10.answer:
Transaction approval rules implement approval requirement logic that cannot be
captured in an authority limit.

Approval routing rules assign approval ownership.

ch09-l11.question: What kind of rules enforce financial holds?
ch09-l11.answer: The correct answer is Transaction Validation rules

ch09-l11.question: In the base ClaimCenter configuration, what happens when a policy’s status is set to anything but “In force” or “Archived”?
ch09-l11.answer: The correct answer is the claim’s Coverage in Question flag is set, resulting in a financial hold.

ch09-l12.question: When and where can service requests be created?
ch09-l12.answer:
The correct answers are:
* During claim creation, in the New Claim Wizard
* After the claim has been created, from the Actions menu

ch09-l12.question: What are the types of Service Request in the base application?
ch09-l12.answer:
The correct answers are:
* Quote Only
* Service Only
* Quote and Perform Service
* Unmanaged Service (for Auto First and Final only)

ch09-l12.question: If you need to add a new service type, what files must you modify?
ch09-l12.answer: The correct answer is vendorservicetree.xml and vendorservicedetails.xml.

ch09-l12.question: After modifying the files, what must you do for the new service type to be available?
ch09-l12.answer: Import the data from the files in the ClaimCenter (and ContactManager) administrator user interfaces.

ch09-l12.question: What do State Transition Helper classes enable?
ch09-l12.answer: The correct answer is Straight-Through Invoice Processing (STIP).

ch09-l12.question: If an invoice comes into the system through a vendor portal, what provides the approval limits for STIP?
ch09-l12.answer:
The correct answer is:

The web service that accepts the invoice is associated with a user, whose permissions
enable that web service.

The approval limits are those of that user.

ch09-l13.question: What is the underlying table for a search criteria entity?
ch09-l13.answer: The correct answer is there is none; it is a virtual, non-persistent entity

ch09-l13.question: What sub-elements can a CriteriaDef element have?
ch09-l13.answer:
The correct answers are:
* Criterion
* CriterionChoice
* ArrayCriterion

ch09-l13.question: What is special about the input widgets on a search page?
ch09-l13.answer:
The correct answer is they represent properties, not of the target entity, but of its
related Search Criteria entity.

ch09-l13.question: After adding a new search criterion to an existing search page, what must be done?
ch09-l13.answer:
The correct answer is:
Regenerate the SOAP and Java APIs.
Redeploy and restart the ClaimCenter server.

ch09-l14.question: What is a ClaimCenter claim history record?
ch09-l14.answer:
The correct answer is an uneditable record of some important event or action taken on
the claim.

ch09-l14.question: If no active rules write claim history records, will any claim history records be written?
ch09-l14.answer:
The correct answer is yes, the base history types are automatically tracked, and do
not depend on rules.

ch09-l14.question: Is it possible to define new types of history events?
ch09-l14.answer:
The correct answer is yes, by adding them to the CustomHistoryType typelist and
creating rules to record them.

ch09-l15.question:
What is the difference between a static permission and an object-based
permission?
ch09-l15.answer:
The correct answer is:
A static permission is granted or revoked for the entire application.
An object-based permission is granted on a claim by claim (or exposure by exposure)
basis.

ch09-l15.question:
What is the difference between a permission and an application
permission key (APK) containing only one permission?
ch09-l15.answer:
Possible answers:
* A permission can be created by a Guidewire configurator, while an APK cannot.
* A permission can be added to a role, while an APK cannot.
* A permissions check using an APK will execute faster than a permissions check
which directly references a permission.

ch09-l15.question:
What is the difference between an APK with two permissions (such as
“create note” and “edit note”) and a role with the same two permissions?
ch09-l15.answer:
Possible answers:
An APK is created to optimize permissions checks. A role is created to assign
permissions to users.
Developers can create and modify roles. Developers cannot create or modify APKs.

ch09-l15.question: If you need to know which roles include the claimown system permission, how would you go about this?
ch09-l15.answer: On the System Permissions page of the security dictionary, look at the roles section of the claimown system permission.

ch09-l15.question: How can you generate or update the security dictionary?
ch09-l15.answer:
1. At the command line, navigate to the ClaimCenter root directory and enter gwb genDataDictionary. The security dictionary is generated along with the data dictionary.
2. On the Export Data page of the Administration tab, you may choose to generate the security dictionary either as HTML or as XML. In either case, the file is then downloaded as a .ZIP.

ch09-l15.question: Given the perm condition perm. System. applyCheck, is applycheck a system permission or an APK?
ch09-l15.answer: It is a system permission. If it were an APK, it would have the entity listed at the beginning of its name.

ch09-l15.question: Given the perm condition perm. System. applyCheck, is applycheck static or object-based?
ch09-l15.answer: Static. If it were object-based, it would have an (object) argument.

ch09-l16.question: What two types of objects can business activity rules create?
What two restrictions are mandatory on a business activity rule?
ch09-l16.answer:
Trigger entity (restricts the business rule to respond to a specific entity)
Trigger action (restricts the business rule to respond to creation, or update action)

ch09-l16.question: What does setting the Rule Condition to None accomplish?
ch09-l16.answer: Setting the Rule Condition to None means that all entities which meet the Trigger Entity, the Trigger Action, and any Applies To values will be processed by this rule.

ch09-l17.question: Under what conditions are exposure rules triggered?
ch09-l17.answer: When an incident is created, each exposure rule compares the incident to its Applies To section and any Rule Conditions; if the incident matches, the rule is triggered.

ch09-l17.question: If a business rule condition accesses the property exposure.VehicleIncident.AirbagsDeployed, what kind(s) of business rule can this be?
ch09-l17.answer: Either a Reserve business rule or an Activity business rule. Exposure creation rules can only directly access the triggering incident.

ch11-l01.question:
Information exchange between systems that use the Internet for direct application-to-application interactions are known as:
A) Messaging
B) Batch Processes
C) Web Services

For each of the InsuranceSuite integration mechanisms, identify its
typical “timing” (synchronous, asynchronous, or scheduled) and initial
direction (outbound or inbound):

Predefined plugins
Web services
Messaging
Startable plugins
Batch processes
ch11-l01.answer:
Predefined plugins — Synchronous and outbound
Web services — Synchronous and inbound
Messaging — Asynchronous and outbound
Startable plugins — Asynchronous and inbound
Batch processes — Scheduled and outbound

ch11-l02.question: What is a package?
ch11-l02.answer:
A package is a group of classes gathered together either because they execute a
common business task, or because access to the classes must be limited only to the
classes in the package, or both.

ch11-l02.question:
A Gosu class is named Circle. Each instance must have a property for
the circle's radius. This value can be accessed and conditionally
modified by methods in the Circle class and by methods in other classes.
How many elements must you create to implement this?
ch11-l02.answer:
Three.
1. A private variable named _radius.
2. A get method that retrieves the value of _radius.
3. A set method that sets the value of _radius.

ch11-l02.question:
The Circle class extends the Oval class and implements the ICurveLine
interface.
1. Can Circle override methods from Oval?
2. Can Circle override methods from ICurveLine?
ch11-l02.answer:
1. Yes
From a keyword standpoint, yes. If Circle implements the ICurveLine interface,
then Circle must implement all the methods of the ICurveLine interface using the
keyword "override". However, because ICurveLine is an interface, the Circle class
is actually just declaring the implementations of the methods. There are no
method implementations in an interface, so there is nothing to "override" from an
OOP standpoint.

ch11-l02.question: What is the purpose of an annotation?
ch11-l02.answer: An annotation provides metadata about the element being annotated.

ch11-l02.question: How do you call a static method from a class?
ch11-l02.answer:
You call a static method by referencing the method name from the class. You must
either reference the fully qualified name of the class or import the class using the uses
keyword followed by the reference to the package path.

ch11-l02.question: Why put logic in a Gosu class as opposed to an entity enhancement?
ch11-l02.answer:
Logic that is reusable and generic must be in a Gosu class.
Logic that is intrinsically connected with an entity must be inserted into an
Enhancement.

ch11-l03.question:
Which approach is used to record a more specific version of the SQL for
a query?
1. queryObj.toString
2. queryObj.withLogSQL (true)
ch11-l03.answer:
A. queryObj.toString
B. queryObj.withLogSQL
The correct answer is B. queryObj.withLogSQL (true)

ch11-l03.question: What is the difference between a query object and results object?
ch11-l03.answer:
A) A query object specifies the entity and the query criteria.
B) A results object is a set of one or more entity instances fetched from the
Guidewire application.
C) This distinction is helpful for understanding the concept of a query and of set of
results. In practice, query results are fetched from the Guidewire application when
they are counted, iterated over, or when one object is retrieved.

ch11-l03.question: Which query restriction uses a block of compare methods?
What happens if you use the AtMostOneRow property in a query, and the query returns more than one object?
ch11-l03.answer:
An exception is thrown when a query that uses the AtMostOneRow property, returns
more than one object.

ch11-l04.question: What is a bundle?
ch11-l04.answer:
A Guidewire bundle is a set of in-memory entities that are saved to the database as a
unit. Each bundle corresponds to one database transaction.

ch11-l04.question:
For each of the following, identify if it's an example of auto commit or manual commit?

A) Queried entities that must be modified
B) Code executed from the UI in edit mode
C) Code executed in business rules
D) Code executed from the UI in read-only mode
ch11-l04.answer:
A) Queried entities that must be modified: Manual commit
B) Code executed from the UI in edit mode: Auto commit
C) Code executed in business rules: Auto commit
D) Code executed from the UI in read-only mode: Manual commit

ch11-l04.question:
What kind of entities are initially put into read-only bundles?
Under what circumstance would you need to copy one of those entities to a writable bundle and how is this done?
ch11-l04.answer:
Entities that are the result of a query are put into read-only bundles, and entities
referenced by foreign key are put into a read-only bundle if the referencing entity is
also in a read-only bundle.

You need to copy these entities to a writable bundle if you need to modify them, which
is done via the bundle's add method.

ch11-l05.question:
Identify if each statement about Gosu Templates is True or False.

A) It can take any number of input values.
B) It can make use of conditional statements and for loops.
C) It can include values from both the object that triggered the message event and objects related to the triggering object.
D) It can be used only for message payload generation.
ch11-l05.answer:
A) It can take any number of input values. True
B) It can make use of conditional statements and for loops. True
C) It can include values from both the object that triggered the message event and objects related to the triggering object. True - Gosu Templates can do this either by having the related objects passed to it or by having the triggering object passed to it and using its foreign keys to navigate to the related objects
D) It can be used only for message payload generation. False

ch11-l06.question:
Identify if each statement about an XML model is True or False.

A) It can take any number of input values.
B) It has a published XSD.
C) It can make use of conditional statements and for loops.
D) It can include values from both the object that triggered the message event and objects related to the triggering object.
E) It can be used only for payload generation
ch11-l06.answer:
A) It can take any number of input values. False — XML models always have a single input, which is the object upon which to base the XML to be generated.
B) It has a published XSD. True
C) It can make use of conditional statements and for loops. False
D) It can include values from both the object that triggered the message event and objects related to the triggering object. True — XML models can do this by including fields from the related objects in the XML model.
E) It can be used only for payload generation. False — XML models can be used anywhere.

ch11-l07.question:
In order to generate JSON wrapper classes, you must: (Select three)

A) Add a new Run/Debug configuration whose main class is defined as: com.guidewire.tools.json.JsonSchemaWrapperCodegenTool
B) Run the server in Debug ‘Server’ mode.
C) Add a package called src.jsonschema.
D) Run the JSONSchemaWrapperCodegen Tool.
E) Restart the server after wrapper classes are created.
F) Add the schema fully qualified name to the codegen-schemas.txt.
ch11-l07.answer: The correct answers are A, D, and F.

ch11-l07.question: X-gw-type is added in a JSON schema to map Guidewire internal types in cases where a format would be ambiguous, such as: typekeys, MonetaryAmount and CurrencyAmount. (True or False)

ch11-l08.question:
Match the HTTP verb with its description:

PUT: Delete from the database
RETRIEVE: Update/Replace row in the database
GET: Create a new record in the database
PATCH: Read from the database
INSERT: Update/Modify row in the database
REMOVE: Not an HTTP verb
POST: Not an HTTP verb
REPLACE: Not an HTTP verb
DELETE: Not an HTTP verb
ch11-l08.answer:
PUT: Update/Replace row in the database
RETRIEVE: Not an HTTP verb
GET: Read from the database
PATCH: Update/Modify row in the database
INSERT: Not an HTTP verb
REMOVE: Not an HTTP verb
POST: Create a new record in the database
REPLACE: Not an HTTP verb
DELETE: Delete from the database

ch11-l08.question:
What file must be updated to publish an API schema?

A) swagger.yaml
B) published-schemas.yaml
C) codegen-schemas.yaml
D) published-apis.yaml
E) json-apis.yaml

ch11-l09.question: What is a WSDL? What does it describe?
ch11-l09.answer:
A WSDL is an XML document that describes how an external system can interact with
a web service.

ch11-l09.question:
What type of files can be included as resources in a SOAP web service
collection?
You have an API instance named “conversionAPI”. Under what circumstances would you set properties on conversionAPI.Config?
ch11-l09.answer:
You would set values there if you needed to provide authentication information,
timeouts, or custom SOAP headers.

ch11-l09.question:
What must be added to a Gosu class in order to make it:
A) A Guidewire SOAP web service?
B) A valid return type for Guidewire SOAP web service methods?
ch11-l09.answer:
A) The @WsiWebService annotation is the only thing required to make a Gosu class
a Guidewire SOAP web service.
B) The @WsiExportable annotation and the keyword "final".

ch11-l09.question:
Identify if the following are true or false about a Guidewire WS-I web service API:
A) It can return a simple value, such as a boolean or string.
B) It can return an instance of any Guidewire data model entity.
C) The WSDL gets generated when you save the class.
D) It can list a set of permissions required to use the API.
E) It can modify Guidewire data.
ch11-l09.answer:
A) It can return a simple value, such as a boolean or string. True
B) It can return an instance of any Guidewire data model entity. False — Instances
of Guidewire data model entities cannot be returned from WS-I web service
methods
C) The WSDL gets generated when you save the class. False - The WSDL is
generated when an external system requests it.
D) It can list a set of permissions required to use the API. True
E) It can modify Guidewire data. False

ch11-l10.question:
Identify if each statement is true or false.
A) Plugins implement methods that are called by internal code.
B) Plugins must be written in Gosu.
C) A plugin class must contain a predetermined set of methods based on the
business need it serves.
D) Plugins are used exclusively for external application integration.
ch11-l10.answer:
A) True
B) False — Guidewire recommends that they be written in Gosu, but they can be
written in OSGi or Java.
C) True
D) False — They are also used to execute tasks exclusively within the Guidewire
application.

ch11-l10.question: What is the purpose of a plugin registry entry?
ch11-l10.answer:
The plugin registry entry identifies the plugin class to use for a given set of internally
called methods and initialization parameters that may be used to affect the plugin's
behavior.

ch11-l10.question:
Do you need to restart the server when you:
A) Modify code in an existing Gosu plugin?
B) Modify a plugin registry entry?
ch11-l10.answer:
A) No, you do not need to restart the server when you make changes to a Gosu plugin
class. However, you need to execute Reload Changed Classes.
B) Yes, you need to restart the server when modifying a plugin registry entry because
plugin registry entries are initialized only during the server application start-up.

ch11-l11.question: What are the five stages of Guidewire messaging?
ch11-l11.answer:
Triggering a message.
Creating a message and payload.
Optionally transform the payload.
Sending the message to an external system.
Processing message acknowledgment.

ch11-l11.question:
What are the three possible statuses for messages that are in the
message table?
ch11-l11.answer:
1. Pending send.
2. Pending acknowledged (sent but no acknowledgement received).
3. Retryable error (sent and an error reported by external system, a negative
acknowledgement or NACk).

ch11-l11.question:
For a Guidewire implementation using clustering, what two server roles
execute the work for messaging? What work is done by each server
role?
ch11-l11.answer: The two clustering server roles are: the ui role and the messaging role.

ch11-l12.question: When does a message event get triggered?
ch11-l12.answer:
Typically, a message event gets triggered when an event-aware entity is created,
changed, or removed.

ch11-l12.question: What is the primary purpose of the MessageContext entity?
ch11-l12.answer:
The primary purpose of the MessageContext entity is to create messages using
information from the message event and the triggering entity.

ch11-l12.question:
A Guidewire application has seven destinations and an event-aware
entity called Escalation.

A) When an Escalation is created, what is the maximum number of
MessageContexts that might get created?

B) What is the minimum?
ch11-l12.answer:
A) Seven, which would occur if all seven destinations listen to EscalationAdded.
B) Zero, which would occur if none of the destinations listen to EscalationAdded.

ch11-l12.question: What plugin is required for every destination? What does this plugin do?
ch11-l12.answer: MessageTransport, which sends the message to the external system.

ch11-l13.question: Why must an Event Fired rule cast the MessageContext Root object?
ch11-l13.answer:
MessageContext.Root is of type Object, but message payloads typically need to work
with the MessageContext.Root as the type of entity that triggered the message event.
Therefore, the MessageContext.Root entity must be cast to be of that type.

ch11-l14.question:
With regards to payload generation and payload transformation:
A) On which server does each take place?

B) At what point in time does each take place?
ch11-l14.answer:
A) Payload generation occurs on the application/UI server. Payload transformation
occurs on the batch/integration server.
B) Payload generation occurs during Event Fired rules (right after the triggering event
occurs). Payload transformation occurs right before the message is sent (in the
request plugin's beforeSend method.

ch11-l14.question:
Under what circumstance would you need to late bind a message
payload?
ch11-l14.answer:
You would need to late bind a message if information that needs to go in the message
payload is not known at the time the message payload is generated in Event Fired
rules.

ch11-l15.question:
Every destination can optionally have a request plugin, but it must have a
transport plugin. Why is the transport plugin required?
ch11-l15.answer:
The transport plugin is required because it is used to send the message when it is
processed from the Message table. Without a transport plugin, messages for a given
destination would have no way of being sent to the corresponding external system.

ch11-l15.question:
Can one destination have two transport plugins? Can one transport
plugin be used by two destinations?
ch11-l15.answer:
A destination can’t have two transport plugins, but a transport plugin class can be used
by two (or more) similar destinations.

ch11-l15.question: Why should the send method never send a message to multiple external systems?
ch11-l15.answer: The message acknowledgement architecture assumes that each message is sent to only one destination. If a given send method sent a message to multiple destinations, then there could be multiple acknowledgements, errors, or unprocessed messages, and the messaging architecture would not be able to identify the state of the message.

ch11-l16.question: What is a messaging acknowledgement from an external system?
ch11-l16.answer: A messaging acknowledgement is Guidewire's process for interpreting a messaging response from an external system.

ch11-l16.question: What are the possible ways Guidewire can interpret an external system's response to a message?
ch11-l16.answer: Guidewire can interpret an external system's response, if one exists, as a positive acknowledgement (ACK), negative acknowledgment (NACK), or duplicate.

ch11-l16.question: Under what three circumstances is an entry added to the MessageHistory table?
ch11-l16.answer: A message is added to the message history table when a message is positively acknowledged, skipped, or retried. For the first two, the message is removed entirely from the Message table. For the third, a copy of the original message remains in the Message table.

ch11-l16.question:
Under what circumstances are acknowledgements processed:
A) By the transport plugin?
B) By the reply plugin?
C) Without involvement from any plugin?
ch11-l16.answer:
A) When the reply is received synchronously.
B) When the reply is received asynchronously through a listener or polling mechanism.
C) When the reply is received asynchronously by an external system call to an API.

ch11-l16.question:
When should you use each of the following methods?
A) aMessage.reportError(retryTime)?
B) aMessage.reportError(errorCategory)?
ch11-l16.answer:
A) When the message needs to be retried and the message has not reached its maximum number of retries.
B) When the message needs to be retried, but the message has reached its maximum number of retries.

ch11-l17.question:
The user, API, and database authentication mechanisms reference which plugin(s)?
A) AuthenticationSourceCreatorPlugin
B) AuthenticationServicePlugin
C) WebservicesAuthenticationPlugin
D) DBAuthenticationPlugin
ch11-l17.answer:
User authentication mechanism references: A) AuthenticationSourceCreatorPlugin
API authentication mechanism references: C) WebservicesAuthenticationPlugin
Database authentication mechanism references: D) DBAuthenticationPlugin

ch11-l18.question: What are the three ways a batch process can be run? Which of the three is the most common?
ch11-l18.answer:
Three way to run a batch process are:
Scheduled
Run from the UI
Run from the web service API
Scheduled is the most common way to run a batch process.

ch11-l18.question: When you add a new batch process typecode to BatchProcess Type, why must you add one or more categories to the typecode?
ch11-l18.answer: The categories of a BatchProcessType typecode determines how the batch process can be run (from the UI, scheduled, from the API, and/or in maintenance level).

ch11-l18.question: When creating a custom batch process, do you need to implement the ProcessesPlugin or just modify it?
ch11-l18.answer:
For PolicyCenter and ClaimCenter, the IProcessesPlugin file already exists in the base application and you only need to modify the ProcessesPlugin class which implements the IProcessesPlugin interface.
For BillingCenter and ContactManager, you need to create an IProcessesPlugin registry file that implements the IProcessesPlugin interface in a new class.

ch11-l18.question: For a custom batch process, what method or methods require implementation?
ch11-l18.answer: Only the doWork method is required.

ch11-l18.question: How does a batch process commit changes to the database?
ch11-l18.answer:
The code must create a new bundle using runWithNewBundle and add the entities to
be changed and committed to that bundle.

ch11-l19.question:
Which plugin interfaces are used for document storage? Which plugin
interface is a required interface?

What are the characteristics of the OOTB default implementation for
document metadata storage and content storage?
ch11-l19.answer:
Document metadata is stored in the Guidewire database and document content is
stored in the file system of the Guidewire application server.

ch13-l01.question:
What are some of the actions that take place in terms of rating after a
quote is requested?
ch13-l01.answer:
Possible answers include:
1. Rating Engine selects a Rate Book
2. The Rating Engine calls a Rate Routine for the Cost Item (for example, coverage)
3. The PolicyCenter Rating Engine constructs the corresponding Worksheet with the
calculated results
4. The results are returned to the calling policy transaction (quote)

ch13-l01.question: What is a rate table?
ch13-l01.answer: A rate table contains static rates in a table format consisting of one or more rows.

ch13-l01.question: What is a factor?
ch13-l01.answer:
A factor is a value in a rate table that can be a rate factor, class, or tier, or as code for
use in further lookups.

ch13-l01.question: What is a parameter set?
ch13-l01.answer:
A parameter set enables users to define the usable information available within a rate
routine.

ch13-l01.question: What is ‘rate flow’?
ch13-l01.answer: Rate flow is the logic in the rating engine plugin that calculates the premium.

ch13-l01.question:
What is the process that an actuary or rating analyst must follow in order
to prepare usable rating content for the configuration developer?
ch13-l01.answer:
Each rating implementation starts from a different place. For example, a rating analyst
may have a spreadsheet with existing rating data or it may be contained in the current
system in another format. Actuaries and rating specialists must create content that is
PolicyCenter ready.

ch13-l02.question: Define a cost and how it relates to a policy’s total cost.
ch13-l02.answer: The Cost is the discrete unit of price for any specific period of time. The total cost of a policy is the sum of the individual costs.

ch13-l02.question:
Describe the difference between the terms: rate scalable and basis
scalable.
ch13-l02.answer:
Rate scalable means that premium is calculated by determining a standard term
amount from base and adjusted rates and then prorating that amount based on the
amount of time the cost applies to the policy.

Basis scalable means the premium is calculated from the value at risk — the basis —
over the policy term. An example is dollars of sales between February 15 and October
1.

ch13-l02.question:
When would a financial transaction have an amount identical to the cost
amount?
ch13-l02.answer:
If a cost has no prior policy period, such as a submission or a renewal, then there is no
difference in the cost. The financial transaction amount is identical to the cost amount.

ch13-l03.question: Describe the relationship among rate routines, rate tables and rate books.
ch13-l03.answer: A rate book is a group of rate tables and rate routines.

ch13-l03.question: What is the purpose of a rate table definition?
ch13-l03.answer: A rate table definition describes the parameters and factors for a particular rate table.

ch13-l03.question: Explain the concept of rate table versions and rate book editions.
ch13-l03.answer:
PolicyCenter creates new rate table versions when you edit a rate table in a rate book.
Active rate books cannot be edited. You must create a new rate book edition to be
able to edit a rate table.

ch13-l04.question: What permission setting allows users to view rating worksheets?
ch13-l04.answer: The user must have the ratingworksheetview permission to be able to view a rating worksheet.

ch13-l05.question: What is the purpose of a rate routine?
ch13-l05.answer: The rate routine provides a way to define the rating algorithm for the rating engine.

ch13-l05.question: How many parameter sets are associated with a rate routine?

ch13-l06.question: When can rating be overridden?
ch13-l06.answer: After obtaining a quote from the rating engine, rates and amounts can be overridden and the policy is rated again.

ch13-l07.question: What is the purpose of impact testing?
ch13-l07.answer: To predict what will happen when a rate book changes.

ch13-l07.question: Can impact testing be run in a production environment?
ch13-l07.answer: No. Impact testing is designed to be run in a test environment on a copy of the production data.

ch14-l02.question: What are CostData objects? How are they named?
ch14-l02.answer: CostData objects are Gosu objects that mirror every cost on a policy graph. Each CostData subclass has the same name as the cost entity followed by the suffix “Data”.

ch14-l02.question: Describe briefly the two CostData constructors.
ch14-l02.answer:
The two CostData constructors are:
- Date-based constructor is created based on effective and expiration dates, usually for a new cost object.
+ Cost-based constructor is created based on a pre-existing cost object that is passed-in as a parameter.

ch14-l02.question: Why are KeyValues needed?
ch14-l02.answer: KeyValues are needed to determine if two CostData objects are the same. The KeyValues property creates a list of the Key Values. The rating engine uses it as it merges CostData objects.

ch14-l02.question: Why can you not set properties directly on cost entities for both FKs?
ch14-l02.answer:
For non-FK properties, you can set the properties directly on the cost entity instance.
For FK properties, this approach does not work, because CostData objects store the
entity's fixed ID encapsulated in a key object. So the methods
setSpecificFieldsOnCost and setFieldValue provided by the CostData class must be
used to set the foreign key properties.

ch14-l03.question: What costs can be rated in slice mode?
ch14-l03.answer: Costs that can be pro-rated based on date and are linear.

ch14-l03.question: What costs can be rated in window mode?
ch14-l03.answer: Costs that cannot be pro-rated based on dates and normally based on CostDatas created in slice mode.

ch14-l03.question: What method can be called to copy standard columns to actual columns?

ch14-l04.question: When should you create a custom physical table?
ch14-l04.answer: In the base configuration there are two physical tables that can be used as-is and as models for other custom tables that may be required for a particular implementation. New custom physical table can be configured for one or a group of similar rate table definitions if neither table is appropriate.

ch14-l04.question: A rate table is normalized for what type of parameters in it?
ch14-l04.answer: A rate table is normalized for range parameters with overlapping ranges.

ch14-l05.question: In which class do you configure rate routine methods available to all Y LOBs?
What property can you set on a parameter so that it can be edited in a rate routine?
